__label__Other ID/CC:  73-year-old man with stage IV-B metastatic esophageal adenocarcinoma presents complaining of three days of constant dizziness.
"__label__Other Source:  Patient, who is a good historian."
__label__Other Past medical records.
__label__Other History of Present Illness  
"__label__cad.mention.before_dct Mr. Vollmer is a pleasant 73-year-old man with a past medical history significant for metastatic esophageal adenocarcinoma s/p XRT and chemotherapy, CAD s/p LAD stent placement, and borderline DM who presents to the Health Care Center complaining of 48-hour history of dizziness and subjective fevers."
"__label__Other He was in his usual state of health until three days prior to admission, when he awoke in the morning with a severe headache."
"__label__Other As he got out of bed, he felt extremely lightheaded."
"__label__Other He describes the dizziness as internal, and    not like the room was spinning."
"__label__Other He laid down, with some resolution of the symptoms."
"__label__Other Of note, he reports that the dizziness is less severe when he lies down and comes on with standing or sitting up."
"__label__Other Throughout the day, he developed a cough productive of green sputum, a subjective fever, continued headache, and nausea without vomiting."
"__label__Other He denied any chills, shortness of breath, chest pain, palpitations, or pain upon deep breathing."
"__label__Other That evening, two nights prior to admission, he developed night sweats but had no rigors."
"__label__Other He continued to feel similarly throughout the day prior to admission, and presented to the emergency room for further evaluation."
__label__Other The current presentation is in the context of increasingly poor PO intake secondary to chemotherapy and treatment for esophageal cancer.
"__label__Other He reports a four-to-five month history of poor appetite, eating chicken soup."
__label__Other He denies any trouble swallowing solids or liquids.
"__label__Other Of note, the day prior to the onset of symptoms, he was NPO for a restaging CT scan."
"__label__Other He reports eating two scrambled eggs after the scan, and a chicken potpie for dinner the night prior to symptoms starting."
"__label__Other In the emergency room, vitals were temperature of 95.6, pulse 52, blood pressure 132/68, RR=20, 95% on room air."
"__label__Other He received Zofran 4 mg IV once, levofloxacin 500 mg PO once, and a NS 500 cc bolus."
__label__Other CXR showed bibasilar infiltrate and bilateral pleural effusions.
__label__Other Oncology History (per attending notes)
__label__Other Patient is a 72 year old man who began having dysphagia 6/83.
"__label__Other On 8/01/83 he was scheduled for a Colonoscopy, so his PCP suggested he have an UGI Endoscopy at the same time."
__label__Other The Colonoscopy demonstrated Diverticulosis and the UGI Endoscopy demonstrated a partially obstructing esophageal/gastric cardia tumor which was biopsied.
__label__Other Pathology revealed moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma.
"__label__Other On 8/10/83 an Abd and Pelvic CT were done showing:  marked thickening of the wall of the distal esophagus (35-40cm by endoscopy - partial obstruction and circumferential) extending into the gastric cardia, consistent with biopsy proven adenocarcinoma."
__label__Other Also felt to be bleeding silently so placed on Fe replacement.
"__label__Other Also, enlarged gastroepiploic, celiac and aortocaval lymph nodes consistent with metastatic disease."
__label__Other On 8/10/83 a Chest CT revealed thickening of the lower esophagus extending into the chest esophageal junction.
"__label__Other This is associated with lymphadenopathy in the (L) axilla, gastrohepatic ligament, celiac axis and retrocrural space."
__label__Other The appearance is highly suspicious for esophageal cancer and nodal spread.
__label__Other There is a 3mm nodule adjacent to the (R) major fissure in the lung.
__label__Other PET scan confirmed axillary and abdominal involvement with cancer.
__label__Other The lung nodule was too small for PET to evaluate.
__label__Other 3/14/84 Restaging work-up revealed progressive disease (see imaging below).
__label__Other His last Taxotere treatment was February 17; further treatment was stopped secondary to a chemotherapy burn on the right arm.

__label__Other I/P: 
__label__Other 73-year-old man with metastatic esophageal adenocarcinoma presents with bibasilar pneumonia and small bilateral pleural effusions.
"__label__Other Pneumonia:  The patient presents with a two-day history of dizziness, subjective fevers, and productive cough of green sputum."
"__label__Other Physical exam reveals decreased bibasilar breath sounds, right greater than left."
__label__Other The constellation of symptoms can be attributed to the pneumonia found on chest imaging.
"__label__Other The possible causes of the pneumonia include aspiration, infectious, and post-obstructive causes."
"__label__Other The patient reports no problems with swallowing and has not vomited, making aspiration pneumonia lower on the differential."
__label__Other The chest CT does not show any evidence of tumor obstruction around the bronchi.
"__label__Other Further, the pneumonia and pleural effusions are bilateral, meaning that the obstruction would have to be higher in the bronchial tree, making obstruction less likely."
"__label__Other In this case the most likely cause is infectious in nature; the agents most likely to cause pneumonia in this patient are the typical bacteria, such as pneumococcus, H. influenza, Staphalococcus, and other gram-negative bugs, atypical bacteria such as Legionella sp, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, and Chlamydia pneumoniae, and viral causes."
"__label__Other Based upon imaging findings, pneumonia most consistent with a bacterial infectious agent."
__label__Other a.
__label__Other Start Levofloxacin 750 mg daily for antibacterial coverage.
__label__Other b.	Sputum gram stain and culture
__label__Other c.	Blood cultures
__label__Other d.	Pneumococcus antigen screening
"__label__Other e.	U/A, urine Legionella"
__label__Other f.	  NS at 75 cc/hour.
"__label__Other If PO intake is not increased, will switch fluids to D5  NS."
"__label__Other g.	Tylenol for fever, Zofran for nausea."
__label__Other h.	Incentive spirometry every two hours while awake.
__label__Other Dizziness:  The patient presents with a two-day history of dizziness.
"__label__cad.mention.before_dct Potential causes include orthostatic causes secondary to hypotension, dehydration, or poor sympthathetic tone; anxiety; cardiac causes (dysrhythmias, CAD), anemia, and electrolyte abnormalities (e.g."
__label__Other hypoglycemia).
"__label__cad.mention.before_dct This patient has a history of CAD, but EKG findings and cardiac enzymes do not suggest cardiac insult."
"__label__Other The patient has not had an increase in the BUN or creatinine from baseline, making dehydration less likely."
__label__Other Labs did not show any electrolyte abnormalities; therefore hypoglycemia is low on the differential diagnosis.
__label__Other The dizziness was positional in nature.
"__label__Other The patient reports long-standing poor PO intake, particularly because he was NPO for much of the day prior to the start of symptoms."
"__label__Other In this patient, the cause of the dizziness is most likely orthostatic in nature, secondary to poor PO intake and decreased sympathetic tone."
__label__Other a.	  NS at 75 cc/hour.
__label__Other b.
__label__Other Check orthostatics daily.
"__label__Other Metastatic esophageal adenocarcinoma:  Patient presents with known Stage IV-B metastatic esophageal adenocarcinoma with new CT findings suggestive of disease progression, particularly in the retroperitoneum."
__label__Other Has been on Taxotere for the last six months.
"__label__Other Patient does not know of new findings, to discuss with Dr. Otero in AM."
__label__Other Consider alternative therapies.

__label__Other Not known to be iron-deficient.
"__label__Other Iron studies (Iron, Ferritin, TIBC) to assess iron deficiency versus anemia of chronic disease."

__label__Other Patient is stable on current regimen.

__label__medication.statin..before_dct Continue with Lipitor 10 mg daily

"__label__Other Patient Name: LILLY, LARRY;  MRN: 2155941"
"__label__Other Dictated on: 11/20/2071 by ANDRE-ISRAEL SANTIAGO, M.D."
"__label__Other DIAGNOSIS:  Bilateral, right greater than left, carpal tunnel syndrome."
"__label__Other HISTORY:  This is a first office visit for this 77-year-old, right-hand-dominant, founder of Bed Bath and Beyond, who comes for evaluation of right greater than left hand and wrist pain."
"__label__Other The patient reports having a longstanding history of greater than four months of worsening pain, paresthesias, and ""numbness"" on the right worse than left hand."
__label__Other This is worse at night and does occasionally wake him up from sleep.
__label__Other Also bothers him during prolonged activity.
"__label__Other He also reports recently over the past few months noting difficulty with the key pinch, grasp, and fine motor function."
__label__Other Previous evaluation consisted of cervical spine MRI as well as EMG nerve conduction studies demonstrating findings significant for severe compression neuropathy of the median nerve at the level of wrist.
__label__Other He now comes for evaluation for potential carpal tunnel surgery release.
"__label__hypertension.mention.during_dct PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  Glucose intolerance, history of previous CVA, status post CABG, hypertension, GER."
"__label__medication.statin..during_dct MEDICATIONS:  Lopressor, Zocor, Ecotrin, Effexor, and Nexium."
__label__Other ALLERGIES:  None.
"__label__Other PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:  On examination today, he is very pleasant, well appearing in no apparent distress."
__label__Other Examination of the right hand demonstrates marked thenar atrophy.
__label__Other There is no active abductor pollicis brevis and 
__label__Other very weak opponens.
"__label__Other He has a positive Tinel's, positive Phalen's, and positive median nerve compression test at the wrist."
__label__Other His interossei and extensors are full.
__label__Other Sensation is intact throughout.
"__label__Other EMG studies from 11/09/2071, performed here at Folsom Convalescent Hospital, significant for right worse than left median nerve compression neuropathy at the wrists."
__label__Other IMPRESSION:  The patient is seen and examined with Dr. Santiago.
"__label__Other At this time, we feel that Larry has indeed a significant, right worse than left, bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome."
"__label__Other Given the amount of weakness and thenar wasting, he has difficulty with abductor pollicis, we have recommended proceeding with both carpal tunnel release as well as "
__label__Other possible FTS of ring finger to thumb tendon transfer.
__label__Other We discussed with Larry the risks and benefits of this procedure and he is in agreement of the plan.
__label__Other We will try to schedule him to proceed with surgery at some point in the near future.
"__label__Other We filled out both history and physical, as well as a surgical consent form today in the office."

__label__Other  Patient is a 76-year-old Croatian woman who came in today.
__label__Other Her daughter Gibbs was translating.
"__label__hypertension.mention.after_dct She is a very complicated 76-year-old Croatian woman with a history of diabetes, hypertension, vertebral basilar insufficiency, chronic hepatitis B and other medical problems."
__label__Other She is status post a right Bell's palsy in the past.
__label__Other Recently she has been sometimes living at her daughter's house and other times at her niece's house.
__label__Other They are trying to provide more support in terms of regulating that she takes her medication.
__label__Other When she stays at her daughter's Gibbs's house her daughter does check her sugars though her niece does not.
__label__medication.arb..before_dct Her blood pressure has been very labile recently and we recently added hydrochlorothiazide and nifedipine extended release 30 mg every day to her regimen in addition to her regular Cozaar and Toprol.
__label__medication.insulin..during_dct Her daughter also has increased her insulin/70/30 to 48 units in the morning.
__label__Other She thinks that sometimes in the afternoon or late afternoon she may have some low sugars.
__label__Other She reports that her mother feels dizzy and has difficulty moving her left leg if her sugar gets low.
__label__Other She feels better if she is given orange juice or something to eat.
__label__Other She has had similar symptoms to that with low sugars in the past however when the daughter checks her sugars they are all in the 174 to 225 range.
__label__Other She has occasional sugars before bedtime that are 337 and 249.
__label__Other The lowest sugar she had was 88 before dinner.
__label__Other The patient reports that she feels dizzy at times.
__label__Other She is a very difficult historian even with her daughter translating or with the other interpreters translating.
__label__Other She has not been having any chest pain or palpitations.
__label__Other Her dizziness is not related to standing up or lying down.

__label__Other Her prior MRI from 07/95 showed chronic lacunar infarcts but no acute hemorrhage or infarct.
__label__Other The patient has had chronic slow speech and there is question about whether or not she has dementia.
__label__Other Her daughter is giving her the Aricept though it is not clear if this is benefiting her or not.
__label__Other Sometimes her daughter thinks that she is actually just being stubborn or uncooperative rather than having difficulties with her memory though other times it seems as if she she does have some dementia.

__label__Other Team 3 Intern

__label__Other Saint Marys Infirmary
__label__Other Pager #44348
__label__Other Record date: 2071-11-23
__label__Other Visit Note
"__label__Other Patient Name: RICO, NATHAN C                     "
__label__Other MRN: 9190908
__label__Other Dictated Date: 11/23/2071                    
__label__Other Dictated By: Leroy Kelly
__label__Other Date of Visit: 11/23/2071
__label__Other Nathan was seen today in routine followup with Clinic Attending Dr. Kim Mays who concurs with the assessment plan that I will outline below.
"__label__Other HISTORY OF THE PRESENT ILLNESS:  Nathan is a 51-year-old, right-handed man who suffered a large right MCA territory stroke in October 2069."
"__label__Other This occurred in the setting of right internal carotid artery occlusion, and hemicraniectomy was required for management of malignant cerebral edema after the stroke."
__label__Other He subsequently developed an infection of the abdominal bone flap.
__label__Other His stroke workup revealed a normal echocardiogram and 24-hour Holter monitor.
__label__Other A hypercoagulability panel was negative.
__label__Other Homocysteine was normal.
__label__Other Serum lipid analysis revealed mild hypertriglyceridemia.
"__label__Other His recovery was complicated by brain abscess, which required surgical drainage and prolonged antibiotic therapy."
__label__Other Finally an artificial bone flap was replaced in October 2070.
__label__Other He then developed persistent nausea and vomiting and a pseudomeningocele.
__label__Other A VP shunt was placed by Dr. Bennett.
"__label__Other Unfortunately, even after shunting there was persistent nausea and vomiting."
__label__Other This turned out to be a side effect of Fentanyl patch use.
"__label__Other The Fentanyl was subsequently replaced with methadone for chronic left-sided neuropathic pain, and the nausea and vomiting abated."
__label__Other I last saw Nathan on April 2nd of this year at which point he was doing quite well.
__label__Other He complained of some hot flashes of unclear etiology.
__label__Other His depression seemed to be under better control on Celexa.
__label__Other Today he reports that he continues to have trouble with neuropathic pain on the left side of his body.
__label__Other Fortunately he has managed to wean himself off of methadone and this has not caused the pain to get any worse.
"__label__Other He is using a substantial dose of Neurontin, which he thinks is helpful."
"__label__Other He complains that these pains involve his face, arm, and leg on the left side and he wonders whether there might be some relationship between the pain and the shunt, which was placed on the left side of his head."
"__label__Other He also complains of occasional leg spasms at night, which are not particularly bothersome."
__label__Other His most significant complaint at this time relates to the hot flashes that he mentioned at our last visit.
"__label__Other These often occur several times daily, although they may not occur for several days at a time."
__label__Other He explains that most of the episodes occur when he is in bed at night.
__label__Other He first develops a feeling of nausea followed by a cold sensation on one side of his body or the other.
__label__Other This has been followed by a feeling of heat from the top of his head down to his toes.
__label__Other There may be a feeling of urinary urgency.
"__label__Other He then experiences a sensation as if he is floating on the bed, and generally this is followed by nausea."
__label__Other The entire episode lasts only seconds but the nausea may persist for as long as an hour.
__label__Other He also notes on some mornings he does not feel like getting out of bed.
"__label__Other He continues to experience depressed mood, and he longs to return to a normal state of functioning."
__label__Other He has returned to volunteering as a Big Brother.
__label__Other He is unable to work.
__label__Other His divorce is now complete and he is really glad about this.
__label__Other He is living with a friend named Tejeda who takes excellent care of him.
__label__Other His left arm remains paralyzed.
__label__Other He has minimal proximal strength in his leg.
__label__Other He has a dense visual field deficit on the left side.
__label__Other He has one new complaint which is a feeling of numbness and tingling in the 4th and 5th fingers on the right side.
"__label__hyperlipidemia.mention.during_dct PAST MEDICAL HISTORY include diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia."
"__label__medication.aspirin..before_dct CURRENT MEDICATIONS include Celexa 20 mg daily, Neurontin 600 mg q.i.d., Phenergan p.r.n., Avandia, Glucophage, Lopressor, Zestril, Pravachol, insulin, and aspirin 325 mg daily."
__label__Other On exam Nathan is well-appearing.
__label__Other His hair has now grown back.
__label__Other On mental status exam he is able to relate a cogent history.
__label__Other He has a number of questions about stroke rehabilitation possibilities including a hyperbaric oxygen program that he learned about in Connecticut.
__label__Other Eye contact is good.
__label__Other On cranial nerve exam pupils are round and reactive and extraocular movements are intact.
__label__Other There is a left visual field deficit.
__label__Other The face is asymmetric with an upper motor neuron pattern left facial droop.
__label__Other The tongue protrudes in the midline.
__label__Other The left arm is completely plegic.
__label__Other The left leg has greater than anti-gravity proximal strength.
__label__Other There is left-sided sensory extinction.
__label__Other Reflexes are brisk on the left and normal on the right.
__label__Other Nathan is able to ambulate with a cane and a left ankle foot orthosis.
__label__Other We spent much of today's visit discussing various issues that concern Nathan.
__label__Other Regarding the possibility of hyperbaric oxygen therapy for stroke rehabilitation.
__label__Other I explained that there is no convincing evidence in favor of this approach.
__label__Other There are some risks to hyperbaric oxygen therapy such as lung injury and the programs are extremely costly.
__label__Other Therefore I advised Nathan not to pursue that option.
"__label__Other Regarding his frequent hot flashes, which are very bothersome, the etiology of these episodes is quite unclear."
__label__Other Dr. Mays mentioned the possibility that these episodes represent some sort of diencephalic paroxysmal discharges.
__label__Other I think it is possible that these are a side effect of Celexa; I believe that they first occurred shortly after starting Celexa.
__label__Other We decided to stop the Celexa for a 2-week period to see if there is any improvement in the episodes.
"__label__Other If there is, I would consider changing to an antidepressant that works by a different mechanism."
__label__Other If there is no change in the episodes we can go ahead and add Celexa back.
__label__Other I neglected to mention above that there is sensory loss to temperature and pinprick in the right hand involving the 4th and 5th digits and the ulnar aspect of the hand on the palmar surface.
__label__Other There is no motor dysfunction in the hand.
__label__Other There is no Tinel's sign over the ulnar nerve at the elbow.
__label__Other The ulnar nerve in the ulnar groove is not hypermobile.
"__label__Other The symptoms and physical exam are consistent with ulnar entrapment neuropathy, which I suspect is the result of arm flexion during sleep."
__label__Other I suggested that Nathan buy an elbow pad with a Velcro strap that will help facilitate keeping the arm straight during sleep.
__label__Other We will keep an eye on this over time.
__label__Other No other changes are indicated at the moment.
__label__Other I intend to see Nathan in followup in about 6 months.
__label__Other ___________________________

__label__hypertension.mention.before_dct Impression: 58 year-old RHF w/ cardiovascular risk factor including HTN/DM/HL/obesity who presents with acute onset of R hand/arm weakness followed by headache/mild nausea.
__label__Other Exam with R pronator drift/orbiting/hand clumsiness with distal>proximal arm weakness.
__label__Other Slow motor initiation is characteristic of corticospinal tract lesion.
__label__Other She has no face or leg weakness.
__label__Other Sparing of face/leg suggests small embolic stroke to the corona radiata in L hemisphere where the motor fiber from face/arm/leg regions are most separated.
"__label__Other However, small capsular stroke is still a possibility."
__label__Other Patient is outside the time window for acute stroke intervention.
__label__Other Recommendations:
__label__Other -Head and neck MRI/MRA
"__label__Other -If MRI shows a stroke, she will likely need to be admitted to RHR Neurology service for stroke workup including TTE, Holter, lipid panel, ESR, homocysteine, lipo(a), PT/OT."
__label__medication.aspirin..before_dct -Change from ASA to Aggrenox for stroke prevention.
__label__medication.statin..during_dct -Continue statin.
"__label__Other -Hold off on her BP med for 24 hours, but likely OK to resume after 24 hours if the stroke size is small."

__label__Other RE:                  Oliver Jain
__label__Other LEPROSARIUM:              962-85-18
__label__smoker.unknown Dear Dr. Colon:
__label__Other I am writing to inform you that I am seeing Mr. Oliver Jain in followup.
"__label__Other Mr. Jain was admitted to my service in transfer for right lower extremity ischemia and gangrene following atheroembolization from a popliteal aneurysm, as you know."
__label__Other He was admitted in early September and stayed until early October.
__label__Other During his hospital stay here his wounds were addressed.
__label__Other He underwent angiograms to evaluate his arterial anatomy and he underwent reconstruction of the right wherein covered stent graft was used to cover disease in his proximal femoral artery and then he underwent an above knee to below knee popliteal artery bypass using PTFE with ligation of the aneurysm.
__label__Other He also subsequently underwent angioplasty of his posterior tibial artery.
__label__Other Given his atheroembolic phenomenon he had very limited vasculature remaining in the foot and I was concerned that the forefoot gangrene would progress and he would wind up losing the right foot.
__label__Other In the interim since his discharge he appears to be doing quite well.
"__label__Other The gangrene of the right foot has remained stable with clearcut demarcation of the right first, second and third toes."
__label__Other He also has some heel ulceration that I am hoping to nurse through.
__label__Other He denies any rest pain or pain in the foot.
"__label__Other He has no evidence of fevers, chills, rigors or shakes in the interim."
__label__Other He has since been discharged to home and has been walking with a walking shoe.
__label__Other His left lower extremity aneurysm is yet to be treated and he has not developed any symptoms with regards to the left lower extremity.
__label__Other He has been taking his Coumadin regularly and has had therapeutic INRs as he reports.
__label__Other On exam today he is doing quite well.
__label__Other He is in good spirits and appears much better than in the hospital.
__label__Other His head and neck exams were unremarkable.
__label__Other His lungs were clear.
__label__Other Heart was regular.
"__label__Other His proximal groin and leg incisions have healed up nicely, however there is some dry eschar on the midportion of the wound."
__label__Other With regards to the toes he has clearcut demarcation and heel ulceration.
"__label__Other There is no evidence of cellulitis, induration or infection of the right lower extremity."
__label__Other He continues to have a stable looking foot on the left.
"__label__Other Given his extensive peripheral vascular disease I performed PVRs in the office today, which revealed that he has pulsatile PVRs at the right calf and ankle."
__label__Other He also has slight pulsatile PVRs at the right transmetatarsal level.
__label__Other This bodes well with regards to his revascularization as well as his potential to either heal or remain stable with regards to the necrosis on the right foot.
"__label__Other His left calf, ankle and transmetatarsal PVRs were similar."
"__label__Other In summary, this is an unfortunate gentleman who developed atheroembolic phenomena resulting in digital ischemia as well as heel ischemia with the potential for limb loss in the near future of the right lower extremity."
__label__Other He does have an untreated aneurysm on the left with potential for atheroembolization of the left lower extremity.
"__label__Other Given this concern, I will proceed next with a left lower extremity revascularization to exclude the popliteal aneurysm so that he does not develop limb-threatening gangrene of the left."
__label__Other With regards to the right I will try to initiate some hyperbaric oxygen therapy and will probably re-evaluate his distal circulation with an angiogram at the time of his next admission or some time thereafter.
__label__Other I am hoping to facilitate healing of the heel wound with the final outcome of a transmetatarsal amputation of the right lower extremity but will see how it goes.
__label__Other My thanks again for this referral.
__label__Other I apologize for not sending you correspondence earlier.
__label__Other With this correspondence I will send you his operative diagram as well as his most recent discharge summary.
"__label__Other Sincerely,"
"__label__Other Quincy T. Uselton, M.D."
"__label__Other Enclosure:  Operative Note, Operative Drawing, Discharge Summary "

__label__Other HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  The patient is a 69-year-old male
"__label__hypertension.mention.after_dct with a history of hypertension, diabetes, coronary artery"
"__label__cad.event.before_dct disease, previous MI, and esophageal cancer with mets to lung,"

__label__Other Thanks very much for referring Mr. Nielson to see me for evaluation of his lymphadenopathy.
__label__Other I will review his history for you.
"__label__Other Mr. Nielson is a 76-year-old gentleman who states that approximately three months ago, he had some increased swelling of his left leg."
"__label__Other About three to four weeks ago, this became increasingly evident and the patient was evaluated at Elders Home in Brandon, Indiana."
"__label__Other At that point, a CT scan was performed."
"__label__Other CT scan of the abdomen revealed significant adenopathy in the retroperitoneal space with a 2.0 cm node between the IVC in aorta and a 1.5 cm node just posterior to that, also a 1.0 cm retrocrural node was seen."
__label__Other CT scan of the pelvis performed on the same day revealed a chain of retrocrural nodes in front of the aorta and vena cava extending to about 2.0 to 3.0 cm below the bifurcation as well as bulky adenopathy in the external iliac chain with an iliac mass measuring 3.0 to 3.5 cm in diameter on the left side.
__label__Other The largest node in the inguinal area measures approximately 6.0 cm in diameter.
__label__Other The patient was then seen by Dr. Lopez on April 12th who noted firm edema in the left leg and referred him to me for evaluation.
__label__Other PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

__label__Other This recurred in 2093.

__label__Other IMAGING STUDIES:

__label__Other ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:  
__label__Other 1.
__label__Other Mr. Danny Nielson is a 76-year-old gentleman with notable lymphadenopathy both by report from the outside hospital as well as by my initial evaluation of his CT scan from Mount Ascutney Hospital.
__label__Other This is very likely to be consistent with lymphoma.
__label__Other I discussed lymphoma in general terms with the patient and his son.
__label__Other I informed them that many lymphomas were treatable and some of them would indeed be curable.
__label__Other This would all depend on the exact histology that was revealed by biopsy.
__label__Other These sites of biopsy would be the left inguinal region.
"__label__Other I informed them that the treatments that would be considered would include either antibodies, chemotherapy or radiation and these would depend significantly on the type of lymphoma that was found."
__label__Other The fact that there are no B symptoms and that he feels relatively well might indicate that this is a low-grade lymphoma.
"__label__Other However, the relatively rapid onset of his leg swelling in the left leg may be more consistent with a higher-grade process."
__label__Other I feel that his left-sided edema is very likely due to decreased lymphatic drainage from the left leg.
"__label__Other However, further discussion of his lymphoma will have to wait final pathology."
__label__Other I introduced the patient to Dr. Victor Ashley who is scheduled to perform a core needle lymph node biopsy later this afternoon.
__label__Other 2.
__label__Other Cardiovascular:  I am very concerned about the patient s history of intermittent burning chest pressure.
"__label__Other If he will be diagnosed with an aggressive lymphoma and will need anthracycline, it would be important to have Cardiology on board."
__label__Other He has a significant murmur and his symptoma are suggestive of angina.
__label__Other The patient will be evaluated by Dr. Square Turk later this week.
"__label__Other In follow-up, Mr. Nielson will see me back in clinic next Sunday six days from now."
"__label__Other At that point, we should have a firm and final biopsy report in hand and the staging studies also have been completed."
"__label__Other At that point, we will be able to discuss therapy in a meaningful way."
__label__Other The patient will call me back if problems arise in the meantime.
"__label__Other Sincerely,"
"__label__Other Gene Quadri, M.D."

__label__Other    Chief Complaint
__label__Other Cardiology Admission Note
__label__Other Christopher Powell
__label__Other # 070 27 68

__label__cad.event.before_dct Mr Powell is admitted to Cardiology clinic s/p cath and PTCA/stent (2.25 x 12 Taxus) to the LAD
__label__Other History of Present Illness
__label__cad.mention.before_dct This 69 yo gentleman has a hx of CAD dating back several years.
__label__cad.mention.before_dct He underwent CABG x 3 in 2092 at WMMC after being diagnosed with CAD after presenting with symptoms of jaw pain and SOB.
__label__Other Immediately after surgery he was told there was likely a problem with one of the grafts.
__label__cad.test.before_dct He began to have symptoms of jaw pain and dypnea within a few weeks of surgery and presented to Beloit State where he had cath within 6 weeks of CABG- at that time his LAD graft was down and his distal LAD was stenosed.
"__label__cad.event.before_dct Failed attempt to stent the distal LAD, but it was PTCA'd with no real relief of his symptoms."
"__label__cad.test.before_dct Last year, he presented here with further progression of his anginal equivalent and underwent cath which showed further stenosis of the distal LAD."
__label__Other There was no PCI option available.
"__label__Other He has been aggressively managed with medications and initially his jaw pain improved, but the dyspnea has persisted."
__label__Other Unfortunately the jaw pain has reoccurred and he has become more symptomatic.
__label__Other He now presented for cath.
__label__cad.test.during_dct Today he arrived via SDA for cath that showed his native disease to be severe with a 70% stenosis involving the ostium of the first diagonal branch.
__label__Other The mid-distal LAD is small and tapering with diffuse disease  up to 80%.
__label__Other The first diagonal has a high grade ostial stenosis.
__label__Other LCX has 40-50% stenosis proximal to the first OM.
__label__cad.test.during_dct RCA has 80% stenosis proximally with competitive flow from the SVG.
__label__Other The LIMA-&gt; D1 is patent and the SVG-&gt; RCA is patent.
__label__Other The SVG-&gt; LAD is not visualized.
__label__Other The mid-LAD lesion was treated with PTCA/stenting with a 2.25 x 12 mm Taxus stent.
__label__Other He arrived on floor 5 pain free and in no distress.

__label__Other following a stringent weight reduction program and decreasing his
__label__Other weight.

__label__Other night.

__label__Other ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
"__label__hypertension.mention.before_dct Ms. Ostrander is a 64 yo Peruvian woman with schizophrenia, HTN, DM2, HL presenting with confusion and found to have significant metabolic disarray including hyponatremia, hypokalemia, hypochloremia and an anion gap."
"__label__Other She also has a mild leukocytosis, anemia &#8211; at baseline, and thrombocytosis."
__label__Other ##: Hyponatremia &#8211; Calculated serum osmolality is 248 mOsm/L (measured 241) suggesting a hypotonic hyponatremia.
"__label__Other Clinically she appears euvolemic, despite having a dry mouth which may be from patient&#8217;s antipsychotics."
__label__Other A Uosm of 62 is most suggestive of primary polydipsia vs. low solute.
"__label__Other Patient is drinking 2L coke/day and complaining of excessive thirst, per PCP/psych notes she is told to limit fluids to 1L."
__label__Other Interestingly this may have been precipitated by switching from diet coke to coke as diet coke contains 30mg Na and 0gm carbs while regular coke contains 45mg Na and 39gm carbohydrates.
"__label__Other Increased carbohydrates with little sodium, protein or potassium load (such as in beer potomania) can inhibit protein breakdown and urea excretion, therefore decreasing daily solute excretion to &lt;250mOsm, which can result in hypoNa if fluid intake is increased."
__label__Other Correct at a rate of &lt;0.5mEq/L/h since she is no longer symptomatic
__label__Other Q6H lytes to ensure correct rate of correction &#8211; prevent osmotic demyelination
__label__Other Fluid restrict to 1L fluid/day
"__label__Other Since she is euvolemic, no indication for NS repletion"
__label__Other Patient refused nutrition consult to discuss dietary choices &#8211; clearly she is making poor dietary choices and her caloric intake is ~800-1000 kcal/day currently from food (+~1000kcal from soda)
__label__Other ##: Protected fall &#8211; History is suggestive of fall in setting of electrolyte distribution and consequential lightheadedness.
"__label__Other Does not seem cardiac in origin, however Q waves in inferior leads appear to have progressed from last EKG on 2/20/67."
__label__Other Protected fall argues against acute arrhythmic event.
__label__Other Check orthostatics
__label__Other Will check cardiac enzymes as EKG is suggestive of progressive Q waves in inferior leads.
__label__Other Monitor on telemetry.
__label__Other Physical therapy consult.
"__label__Other ##: Anemia &#8211; Hct at baseline, however was iron deficit in 6/65 and had a tubular adenoma resection on colo.  Will repeat iron studies to ensure iron replete."
"__label__Other Fe, TIBC, ferritin"
__label__Other Consider repeat outpt colonoscopy to r/o GI malignancy/lesion contributing to anemia
__label__Other ##: Elevated anion gap.
__label__Other Delta-delta is 8/6=1.3= Pure metabolic acidosis.
__label__Other Osmolar gap is &lt;10 so ingestion is less likely.
__label__Other There are no ketones in the UA and there is no evidence of renal failure.
__label__Other pH is not suggestive of an acidosis.
__label__Other AG is likely from severe metabolic disarray (decreased anions and cations).
__label__Other Check lactate
__label__Other Repeat AG
"__label__Other ##: Leukocytosis - no evidence of infection, although infection could contribute to confusion."
__label__Other UA and CXR were negative.
__label__Other If persistent or febrile will obtain cultures.
__label__Other Repeat CBC

__label__Other Dear Dr. Townsend:
__label__Other 	I had the pleasure of seeing Nancy Xayarath today with regards to callus formation over the plantar aspect of her left foot.
"__label__diabetes.mention.after_dct As you are aware, she is a 57-year-old woman with a history of insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus and Charcot arthropathy of her left foot that has resulted in a rocker bottom deformity."
__label__Other She currently wears accommodative orthotics typical for somebody with her deformity.
__label__Other She has noted that perhaps over the last two weeks or so that a callus has formed under the plantar lateral aspect of the left foot.
"__label__Other She denies any drainage, erythema, or increased swelling or warmth in the foot."
__label__Other Her orthotics were made in September and seem to be working quite well for her.
__label__Other She admits however that over the last month and half or so that she has been wearing boots that her current orthotics do not fit in.
"__label__Other Apparently, she has had to resort to her old orthotics, which did not take her Charcot deformity into account."
__label__cad.mention.before_dct Her past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus and coronary artery disease.
"__label__medication.aspirin..before_dct Her medications include Prograf, prednisone, Prilosec, an aspirin a day, Imdur, calcium supplement, a multi vitamin, Lantus insulin, and Humalog with meals."
"__label__medication.beta_blocker..during_dct She takes Imuran, Coumadin, and Toprol XL, as well as Lipitor."
"__label__Other Her past surgical history is significant for colostomy in 2094, fistula repair in 2095, coronary artery bypass surgery times four in 2096, a kidney transplant in 2097, and a fistula ligation in 2098."
__label__Other She quit smoking ten years ago and has no known allergies to medications.
__label__Other Physical examination is centered mainly around her left foot.
__label__Other She has diminished sensation to ten-point examination with a Semmes-Weinstein 5.05 monofilament.
"__label__Other She has multiple toe amputations, all of which have healed nicely."
__label__Other She does have a palpable dorsalis pedis pulse.
__label__Other The skin is of normal turgor.
__label__Other She has no active plantar ulcers on 
__label__Other Page two
__label__Other Re:  Nancy Xayarath
"__label__Other Date: February 17, 2100"
__label__Other either foot.
__label__Other At the apex of her rocker bottom deformity on the left side there is a callus that I d  brided in the office underlying which is a grade 0 ulcer.
__label__Other No new x-rays were obtained today.
"__label__Other Diagnosis: Grade 0 ulcer, diabetic left foot."
"__label__Other Plan:  She has not reached the dermis on her left foot, however, should she continue to weight-bear without mechanical off-loading it is only a matter of time before this develops into a grade I ulcer."
__label__Other It is unclear to me whether the culprit is an orthotic that needs to be remolded or the fact that she has been wearing boots with an inappropriate orthotic.
"__label__Other I am going to have her see Samantha Albright, our orthotist to have the insoles remolded with Plastizote."
__label__Other I have asked Ms. Xayarath to bring the shoes that she typically wears as well as the boots she wears.
__label__Other We will follow this development closely as Ms. Xayarath is perfectly aware of the potential downsides of forming an ulcer.
__label__Other She knows to contact me if she has any questions or concerns in the meantime.
__label__Other Thank you kindly for this referral.
"__label__Other Best personal regards,"

"__label__Other RE: URQUHART, WENDELL Y"
__label__Other MRN: 5747359
__label__Other DOB: 11/22/2072
__label__Other Dear Dr. Overman: 
"__label__Other I had the pleasure of seeing your patient, Wendell Urquhart, in consultation today."
__label__Other The patient presents complaining of lower back pain with right lower extremity radiation.
__label__Other He develop symptoms gradually three months ago with no history of preceding trauma.
__label__Other The symptoms became progressively worse.
__label__Other The patient has a history of lower back injury 30 years ago in a motor vehicle accident - at that time he was diagnosed with disc rupture.
__label__Other Currently the pain is intermittent and occurs daily.
__label__Other He grades the intensity of the pain as up to 7 to 8 out of 10 on the numerical pain scale.
__label__Other He describes it as sharp shooting sensation in the lower back with radiation all the way down right lower extremity to the foot.
__label__Other The symptoms are worse with standing; better with sitting and lying down.
__label__Other There is no change in the intensity of symptoms with coughing or sneezing.
"__label__Other The patient any recent fever or chills, no loss of bowel or bladder control."
__label__Other He describes occasional intermittent numbness in the right leg and foot.
__label__Other He denies any weakness.
__label__Other He lost 30 pounds through dieting over the past two months.
__label__Other The pain does not wake the patient up at night.

__label__Other Just a note for the records regarding Ms. Xanders's recent admission to our Cardiology Service between 08/09/2087 and 08/12/2087.
"__label__diabetes.mention.after_dct As you know, she is a lovely 47-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes, hypertension, cigarette smoking and end-stage renal disease for which she underwent transplantation in 2083."
__label__Other She is now under evaluation for pancreatic transplantation.
__label__Other She has not had symptoms of angina or left ventricular dysfunction and LVEF has been normal.
"__label__Other An exercise test in July 2087 achieved 79% of the maximal predicted heart rate, no chest discomfort, but 1-mm of ST depression in the lateral leads."
"__label__Other Her other recent issues have included marked anemia, possibly related to her immunosuppressive drugs (negative upper and lower endoscopy) and transient hyperglycemia following a glucocorticoid bolus."
"__label__Other At the time of admission, the hematocrit remained in the low 20s and she was transfused in preparation for cardiac catheterization."
"__label__smoker.current Appropriate bicarbonate and Mucomyst therapies were administered, and we also took advantage of the precatheterization time to reinforce the importance of smoking cessation."
__label__Other Coronary angiography on 08/11/2087 demonstrated a co-dominant system with chronic occlusion of the right coronary artery with left to right collaterals perfusing that territory.
__label__Other There was also a 95% stenosis of the proximal LAD.
"__label__Other After careful consideration of the options, Dr. Valdez placed a Cypher stent at that location successfully."
"__label__Other She tolerated the procedure well,  was ambulatory the following morning and the creatinine had actually improved to 2.0; the hematocrit remained ""stable"" in the mid 20s."
"__label__Other She will likely be discharged later today, following a discussion with the renal transplant service regarding augmenting her antihypertensive regime."
"__label__medication.thienopyridine..after_dct She understands the importance of uninterrupted clopidogrel therapy,  preferably for more than one year."
__label__Other It was a pleasure to participate in Ms. Xanders's care.

__label__Other Over the past six weeks he had reported a slow decline in respiratory function  prompting a recent admission here 1/23 -25/77 for elective bronchoscopy to rule out rejection.

__label__Other Pt reports continued slow improvement in dyspnea following discharge.
__label__Other Yesterday morning he developed watery diarrhea (no blood or mucus) soon followed by nausea and vomiting (no blood or coffee grounds).
__label__Other He went to BOGC and describes feeling increased dyspnea.

__label__Other GI symptoms have since improved and pt is tolerating PO.

__label__Other WISNER FAMILY PRACTICE

__label__Other Dear Fitzgerald:
"__label__Other   I had the pleasure of seeing your patient, Haden Doty, in consultation today regarding his peripheral arterial disease and generalized vascular disease."
"__label__cad.mention.before_dct As you know, he is a patient that has known coronary artery disease, for which I ended up doing a catheterization on 08/27/2157, and that was done because of an abnormal stress test and chest pain."
"__label__cad.test.before_dct At that time, he had been evaluated by Dr. Morgan Thayer, who performed a stress MIBI and demonstrated an inferoposterior ischemia, a low workload of 3 minutes and 18 seconds, and a heart rate of only 72% of predicted."
"__label__Other The LV chamber was dilated, and the ejection fraction was estimated at 48%, and there was a suggestion of global ischemia."
"__label__cad.mention.before_dct The catheterization demonstrated the presence of moderate diffuse coronary artery disease, plaque distributed throughout much of the coronary tree, some calcification, and narrow caliber vessels overall, but no focal high-grade stenoses."
"__label__Other There was some disease in the distal left main coronary artery, but his angina or ischemia was felt to be on the basis of excess demand in the phase of globally diminished supply."
__label__cad.mention.before_dct He was treated medically for the coronary artery disease.
"__label__Other At the time of his cath, he also underwent an angiography of his abdominal aorta and selective angiogram of his left leg, because he was complaining of claudication predominantly on the left calf at that time."
"__label__Other That study demonstrated the presence of two renal arteries of the left side, a small superior one that was narrowed by about 50%, and a larger inferior left renal artery that was narrowed by about 60%."
__label__Other The right side was patent.
"__label__Other With respect to the abdominal aorta, there was an ulcerated plaque just below the superior renal artery, narrowing the channel in the aorta by about 30% or 40%."
"__label__Other The iliac vessels were patent, and the left common femoral artery had some irregularity that was patent."
"__label__Other The left SFA, a diffusely diseased vessel, had a high-grade stenosis of about 80% in the adductor canal."
"__label__Other Then, at the trifurcation, there was occlusion or high-grade stenosis of all three trifurcation vessels on the left side."
__label__Other There was reconstitution at the level of the ankle.
"__label__Other The decision at that time was made to treat him conservatively, at least for the present, since he was still playing golf three to four times a week."
"__label__Other He also apparently had some other issues, so I never saw him again in followup."
__label__Other The original plan had been to bring him back for revascularization of his left renal artery and the left SFA.
__label__Other He did have back surgery about a year ago when he became significantly crippled by his lumbar spinal stenosis.
"__label__Other Dr. Anders Sykes performed an L3-L4, L4-L5 decompressive laminectomy."
__label__Other This had a dramatically positive effect on his back pain.
__label__Other The biggest problem now is that he feels that he cannot walk as far and his exercise tolerance has decreased.
"__label__Other He has been an avid golfer in the past, but is now having some more difficulty with that."
"__label__Other Even when I saw him two years ago, he was using a cart to play three or four times a week."
"__label__Other He still is able to play golf, but if he walks about 100 yards, he starts feeling his calves, and now the symptoms are bilateral and equal."
"__label__Other He also has some numbness in his toes, which is constant, and his feet feel cold much of the time."
__label__Other The symptoms of claudication have increased over the past couple of years.
__label__Other His blood pressure has been reasonably stable.
__label__Other He tells me that you get pressures of 120-130.
"__label__Other He has not been taking his blood pressure at home, but he does take a fair amount of medication, see below."
"__label__Other Of note, his son says that when he was in Michigan, he was playing 18 holes of golf regularly, sometimes a couple of times per day, but Haas notes that he was indeed limited by claudication even though he was able to play the golf down in Michigan."
__label__Other He seems to be more limited up here since returning just a short time ago.
"__label__Other He also says that he feels like he has got to stay on the move, and if he does not play any golf at all, he will really deteriorate."
"__label__Other Of note, the discomfort is not only limited to the calves, but also there is some discomfort in the hips, though not nearly as bad and not as limiting."
"__label__Other Of note, he has been seeing Dr. Youngman for his legs and has been told to ""walk walk walk."""
"__label__Other At this point, he feels that he cannot walk as well or enough to follow through on his instructions."

__label__Other HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
"__label__Other Mr. Ishida is a 78 y/o, who p/w dizziness that began 2 to 3 weeks ago."
__label__Other The pt says the dizziness was worsened when he stood up to walk around; noting that it was particularly bad when he was standing and concentrating on a particular task such as shaving.
__label__Other The dizziness was alleviated by him lying down.
__label__Other He added that he began feeling dizzy during the storm last week when his drinking water was contaminated.
"__label__Other He drank tap water until he was told it was undrinkable, then he stopped."
__label__Other He later developed diarrhea while not drinking any water and only having occasional Coca-cola beverages.
"__label__Other During these 2 weeks of dizziness, Mr. Ishida notes he felt that he lost 3-4 days of his life, saying that he was either knocked out or unconscious."
__label__Other He came to this conclusion b/c his medication box was still full for the previous 3 days; supporting his reflection by saying he rarely ever misses his medication.
__label__Other Mr. Ishida states that the room was not spinning and said that his dizziness was more like &#8220;lightheadness.&#8221; He feels that his problems began when taking Tylenol- 2 weeks ago and cannot identify any other medication that is associated with his symptoms.
"__label__Other Mr. Ishida says he&#8217;s never experienced any dizziness before, and hoped his symptoms would subside if he just stayed in bed."

__label__Other ASSESSMENT
"__label__hypertension.mention.before_dct Mr. Ishida is a 78 y/o M with h/o CKD, HTN, and NIDDM p/w sustained dizziness and altered mental status."
__label__Other Mr. Ishida is most likely currently in a volume depleted stated.
__label__Other He had diarrhea induced by the contaminated water from the storm and only maintained his hydration with a meager 2 or 3 bottles of Coca-cola over several days.
"__label__Other This in combination with his output of fluid from diarrhea, his diuretic medication, and possible osmotic diuresis (increased serum glucose level from soda intake in a diabetic) could have shifted him into hypovolemia."
"__label__Other Thus Mr. Ishida might have decrease effective arterial volume causing his BUN/Cr ratio to be elevated, indicating a prerenal process."
"__label__Other Although BUN/Cr ratio is not &gt;20, we can still assume that he has prerenal ARF considering his use of diuretics and h/o CKD which can decrease the sensitivity of BUN/Cr rations and FENa for assessing etiologies of renal failure."
__label__Other Mr. Ishida additionally uses NSAIDs (e.g.
"__label__medication.arb..before_dct Naproxen), an ARB and an ACEI, all of which are associated with decreased intraglomerular pressure and renal vasoconstriction which can lead to prerenal ARF."
__label__Other Intrinsic ARF is less likely considering he is not using any overtly nephrotoxic drugs (e.g.
"__label__Other amphotericin, cisplatin, or aminoglycosides."
"__label__hyperlipidemia.mention.during_dct Conversely, he is at an increased risk of cholesterol emboli given his h/o of hypercholesterolemia and vasculopathy."
"__label__Other Lastly, Mr. Ishida my have a postrenal ARF etiology considering his h/o BPH which could lead to obstruction of the outflow tract leading to increased pressures in the ureters flowing back up into the kidneys."
__label__Other Mr. Ishida&#8217;s dizziness and altered mental status are both explained by ARF.
"__label__Other Additional explanations of altered mental status are ruled out via the history and physical including intoxication, brain hemorrhagic, brain tumor, etc."
__label__Other PLAN
__label__Other #) Acture Renal Failure
__label__Other -Continue fluids and hydration: 1L of IV saline over the next 24 hrs
__label__Other -D/c naproxen use.
__label__Other -Rule out Post-renal etiology: use ultrasound to assess the size of the bladder and ureters.
__label__Other If enlarged bladder and ureters are found the diagnosis is more likely postrenal ARF due to an enlarged prostate.
__label__Other Thus the patient should be assessed by Urology of possible partial prostatectomy.
__label__diabetes.mention.after_dct #) DM
__label__medication.metformin..before_dct -Discontinue metformin due to possibility of metabolic acidosis and hospital drug interactions.
__label__cad.mention.before_dct #) CAD
__label__medication.beta_blocker..after_dct       -Switch Atenlol to metoprolol given ARF
__label__hypertension.mention.before_dct #) HTN
"__label__medication.ace_inhibitor..before_dct -Discontinue lisinopril, valsartan, furosemide until pt&#8217;s renal condition improves."
__label__Other #) Gout
__label__Other       -D/C allopurinol until pt&#8217;s renal condition improves
__label__hyperlipidemia.mention.after_dct #)Hypercholesterolemia
__label__medication.statin..after_dct -Continue simvastatin as previously prescribed (Simvastatin  20 MG PO QHS)
__label__Other #) Psoriasis
__label__Other -Continue Ammonium Lactate 12% Cream and Calcipotriene 0.005%   TOP BID prn
__label__Other #)Benign Prostate Hypertrophy
__label__Other       -Continue Finasteride and darifenacin as previously prescribed.

__label__Other INFECTIOUS DISEASE UNIT
__label__Other NORTHERN STATE HOSPITAL
__label__Other Visit Note (unreviewed)
__label__Other Reason for visit   f/u for inpatient consult - GBS AV endocarditis
__label__Other History of present illness   See initial ID consult note for greater detail.
"__label__hypertension.mention.before_dct Briefly, 70 yo F w HTN, DM2, stable angina who is transferred to NSH on 4/3/89 with aortic valve endocarditis complicated by AI and CHF."
__label__Other She was in her USOH until ~2/8/89 when she had an episode of shingles on R arm for which she took Valtrex.
__label__Other Soon after she began to feel fatigued and febrile and was found to have a 2/2 bottles positive for Group B streptococcus on 2/21 (PCN MIC 0.125) for which her PCP treated her with 2 week course of amoxicillin.
"__label__Other On 4/3 she presents with SOB, orthopnea, and PND."
"__label__Other she developed DOE, PND, orthopnea, worsening fatigue and malaise."
__label__Other CXR at OSH notable for pulm edema and TTE demonstrated vegetation on the aortic valve.
__label__Other She was transferred to NSH where she was started on ampicillin 1gm IV q8h and gentamicin 120 mg TID.
__label__Other TTE 4/4 showed a mobile mass of echoes attached to the valve c/w vegetation.
"__label__Other The right coronary leaflet appears flail, and there was prolapse of the non-coronary cusp as well."
__label__Other There was evidence of at least moderate aortic insufficiency by color and spectral Doppler.
"__label__cad.event.before_dct She went to the OR on 4/5 CABG, TEE, Homograft aortic root placement oIn the OR the aortic valve was severely damaged."
"__label__Other There was perforation of the right coronary leaflet and there were numerous vegetations, which appeared to be rolled up aortic valve tissue on predominantly the right and noncoronary leaflets."
"__label__Other Underneath the annulus of the right coronary, there was an area of early abscess "
__label__Other formation.
__label__Other Gram stain of tissues was negative for organisms and cultures were negative.
__label__Other Pathology was notable for Numerous degenerated bacterial coccal forms present on silver stain consistent with Streptococcus.
__label__Other Occasional residual gram positive cocci present on Brown-Hopps stain.

__label__Other ASSESSMENT:
__label__Other Progressive renal dysfunction in the setting of severe bilateral renal artery stenosis for consideration of reno-vascular disease.
__label__Other PLAN:
__label__Other 1.
"__label__Other His MRA of abdomen was reviewed with Dr.Quilici, BHCC IR department."
__label__Other Aorta is fully occluded beneath the level of both kidneys.
__label__Other Tight renal artery stenosis noted in both kidneys.
__label__Other Both proximal and distal stenosis noted in the Rt renal artery.
__label__Other Both kidneys appeared normal in size 11.2 and 11.4 cm.
__label__Other Dr.Quilici is confident that renal angioplasty could be done relatively safely through radial artery approach.
__label__Other 2.
"__label__Other We have requested Dr.Xi, Vascular surgeon to get his opinon on the need for surgical revascularisation of feet to save his legs from critical ischemia in the future."
"__label__Other If so, whether he would benefit from surgical revascularisation of the kidneys."
__label__Other We are awaiting his expert opinion.
__label__Other 3.
__label__Other Patient realises that renal angiogram + angioplasty thro' radial artery carries its own risk.
"__label__Other Risks of Cholesterol emboli, Contrast nephropathy, arterial injury, risk of further deterioration of his kidney function leading to early initiation of dialysis are explained."
__label__Other However patient feels that it worth taking a choice to prevent the kidneys from worsening rapidly by attempted angiopalsty.
__label__Other 4.
__label__Other We will obtain renal ultrasound to again measure his kidneys and to rule out any obstructive uropathy as the cause of renal dysfunction.
__label__Other 5.
"__label__Other If patient is going for IR renal angiogram/plasty, then he will need Contrast prophylaxis."
__label__Other We will review him tomorrow with Dr.Xi's opinon.

__label__Other His renal arteries have ostial stenoses bilaterally.

"__label__diabetes.mention.after_dct PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Hypothyroidism, type 2 diabetes, asthma."

"__label__Other His mental status, cranial nerve examination, strength and sensation were normal."

"__label__obese.mention.after_dct He is able to ambulate approximately two flights of steps, but at the top of the steps develops slight dyspnea on exertion, unclear whether or not this is related to a cardiac etiology or secondary to his morbid obesity with his weight over 400 pounds."
"__label__Other He denies any heart failure symptoms, orthopnea, PND, lower extremity edema or nocturia though he has been maintained on Lasix diuresis in the past though none currently."

"__label__obese.mention.after_dct Past medical history is remarkable for hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, insulin dependent diabetes mellitus and morbid obesity."

"__label__hypertension.mention.after_dct Impression:  Mr. Rivers is a very pleasant 47-year-old gentleman with multiple cardiac risk factors, notably insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus as well as poorly controlled hypertension with no known coronary artery disease now presenting for cardiovascular clearance prior to elective hip repair scheduled for three days from now."
"__label__Other This gentleman has no known coronary disease and has a reasonable exercise capacity, which I estimate to be 3 to 5 METS."
"__label__Other Most recently, given his hip and orthopedic issues, he has been unable to ambulate even to three METS."
"__label__Other However, prior to his orthopedic injury several months ago, he was able to ambulate up two flights of steps with only minimal dyspnea upon reaching the top step and without any exertional chest discomfort."
"__label__hypertension.mention.after_dct However, given his multiple risk factors, notably his poorly controlled diabetes and poorly controlled hypertension as well as former tobacco use, he certainly is at very high risk for obstructive coronary disease."
"__label__Other As such, I recommended we obtain a Persantine PET stress test for tomorrow morning."
"__label__Other If this test is normal without any high risk features or without any evidence for obstructive coronary disease, it would be reasonable for him to proceed with surgery later on this week."
"__label__Other This test will also suffice for his upcoming gastric laparoscopic bypass surgery, which is scheduled for 01/2074."
"__label__Other With regards to his medication, his blood pressure still is not at goal below 130."
"__label__medication.beta_blocker..before_dct As such, I have increased his Toprol-XL from 125 mg to 200 mg p.o."
__label__Other This medication should be continued through all surgery.
"__label__Other Additionally, if this is not sufficient in bringing his blood pressure down below 130, I would recommend the addition of a diuretic to his regimen either Lasix 20 mg p.o."
__label__Other daily or hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg p.o.
"__label__diabetes.mention.after_dct Additionally, it will be essential that his diabetes be taken better control of and he is now working closely with the diabetes center here at the KCM to do so."
__label__diabetes.a1c.before_dct His last A1c was approximately 13 and this is certainly way out of range for someone of his young age.
__label__Other I am hopeful with continued medical therapy this gentleman can continue to improve his life and undergo orthopedic surgery as well as gastric bypass surgery with significant improvement to his quality of life and future cardiac risk.
"__label__medication.beta_blocker..before_dct With regards to his hypertension, he is on multiple agents including Toprol-XL, Aldactone, Avapro and minoxidil."
"__label__hypertension.mention.after_dct Given the multitude of agents, it would be reasonable to screen this gentleman for secondary causes of hypertension including hyperthyroidism as well as hyperaldosteronism, but notably he has currently started the Aldactone and this would be difficult to do while on the medication."
"__label__Other We could consider in the future, if his blood pressure is not well controlled either washing out the Aldactone and then followed by renin and aldosterone testing versus BLANK sampling in the future if deemed necessary."
"__label__Other Additionally, if he is found to have coronary artery disease, one other option despite his lack of claudication would be evaluation of renal artery stenosis."
"__label__Other As mentioned, I will obtain the stress imaging tomorrow morning and then we will be able to have a better assessment of whether or not it would be reasonable to proceed with surgery in the near future."
__label__Other I will follow back with him in approximately several months' time for followup of his general cardiovascular care.

__label__Other patient's heart rate.

__label__Other proceed with cardioversion.

__label__Other Ativan and had a synchronized cardioversion once at 52 volts with 
__label__Other immediate change to sinus tachycardia in the 1 teens.

__label__Other stated that his chest tightness resolved immediately following 
__label__Other cardioversion.

__label__Other and he seems to be doing very well from a cardiovascular
__label__Other perspective.
__label__Other Apparently he has had guaiac positive stools and has
__label__Other undergone a colonoscopy with the identification of four polyps.
__label__Other Three have been removed and he then had a GI bleed.
__label__Other This has been
__label__Other reevaluated and he has been stable.
__label__Other The fourth polyp will need to
__label__Other be removed at a later time.
"__label__medication.aspirin..before_dct At this point, his aspirin has been"
__label__Other discontinued for a number of days and the Lopid was also
__label__Other discontinued apparently because of increased liver function tests.
"__label__Other His current medications therefore include Lasix 40 mg per day,"
"__label__medication.beta_blocker..after_dct Metoprolol 25 mg qd, Nifedipine XL 30 mg qd."
__label__Other He is aware of a
__label__Other belching and burping sensation after eating but otherwise no
__label__Other exertional or other related symptoms.
__label__Other He is reasonably active but
__label__Other somewhat limited by his claudication.
"__label__Other On exam today, he is comfortable with a blood pressure of 130/70,"
__label__Other a heart rate of 65 and regular.
__label__Other Head and neck were unremarkable.
__label__Other Chest is clear.
__label__Other Cardiac exam showed no jugular venous distension
__label__Other at 30 degrees.
__label__Other PMI is normal.
__label__Other S1 and S2 are normal with a
__label__Other physiologic split.
__label__Other There is an S4 and a I/VI systolic ejection
__label__Other murmur at the left sternal border.
__label__Other Abdominal exam was
__label__Other unremarkable.
__label__Other Extremities showed no edema or cyanosis.
__label__Other His resting 12-lead electrocardiogram demonstrates normal sinus
__label__Other rhythm with left axis deviation and a nonspecific left
__label__Other intraventricular conduction delay.
__label__Other Page 2
__label__Other I think Mr. Umstead is basically doing quite well.
__label__Other It would be of
__label__Other value to repeat an exercise test since he has not had one since
__label__Other 2069.
__label__Other He had minimal ischemia at that time.
__label__Other There are no symptoms
__label__Other that would prompt cardiac catheterization at this point and we will
__label__Other see how he does on the exercise test with the objective findings.

__label__Other 	Reason for visit:
"__label__cad.event.before_dct    Mr. Bell is an 81 year old male with recent CABG, now admitted via EW with progressive shortness of breath and hypoxia for further evaluation."
__label__Other Interval History:
__label__cad.mention.before_dct    He has multiple cardiac risk factors and a history of CAD dating back to April 2097.
"__label__Other At that point, he noted increasing chest pressure and dyspnea on minimal exertion."
"__label__cad.test.before_dct Following a positive stress test, he was admitted for cardiac catheterization."
__label__cad.mention.before_dct Coronary angiography revealed severe multi vessel CAD.
__label__cad.event.before_dct He had an IABP placed and underwent cardiac surgical evaluation.
__label__Other Carotid non-invasive studies revealed a moderate right carotid lesion with mild left carotid disease.
__label__cad.event.before_dct He underwent a 4 vessel CABG by Dr. Troyer.
"__label__Other His graft anatomy includes a LIMA to the LAD, SVG to the PDA and PLV and a SVG to the OM branch."
__label__Other He required re-exploration for bleeding.
"__label__Other He also had atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response, treated with Amiodarone."
__label__Other His IABP was removed a few days post operatively.
"__label__Other He developed new anterior ST changes, and an echocardiogram revealed a marked decline in his LV function from 66% to 19%."
__label__Other He was taken emergently to the cardiac catheterization lab.
"__label__Other Coronary angiography revealed a widely patent SVG to OM, a 30% ostial lesion in the SVG to the PDA and PLV."
"__label__Other The LIMA was patent, but there was no flow into the distal LAD."
"__label__cad.event.before_dct He underwent stenting of the LIMA anastomosis into the LAD with a 2.5mm x 18mm, 2.5mm x 12mm and 2.5mm x 12mm MiniVision stents."
__label__Other His post cardiac surgical course was further complicated by a Serratia pneumonia and a transient worsening renal function.
__label__Other He also required sternal rewiring for sternal instability.
__label__Other He was followed by Dr. Hardin.
__label__Other His HIT assay was borderline negative.
"__label__Other He was also found to have a factor VII deficiency, and was treated with argatroban."
"__label__Other Lower extremity non-invasive studies revealed a R posterior tibial DVT, and he was discharged on Fopndaparinux."
"__label__Other A follow up echocardiogram revealed an ejection fraction of 31% with apical akinesis, with only mild mitral regurgitation."

__label__Other He was discharged from rehab on June 5th.

__label__Other VATS biopsy on 9/27 showed usual interstitial pneumonitis with extensive smooth muscle metaplasia - a rather unusual reading.

"__label__Other For example, he notes that going up the four stairs to the house with bundles he is mildly short of breath and has to rest."

"__label__Other He has no leg edema, chest pain, skin rash, joint problems, or fevers."
__label__Other He has managed to lose 6 lbs.
"__label__Other by giving up sweets, and his sugars are slightly better."

__label__obese.bmi.during_dct (BMI 38).

__label__Other 1.
"__label__Other Biopsy-proven idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis - The biopsy reading is somewhat unusual, and I will review this at our Pulmonary group weekly meeting, particularly with an eye to agents that might possibly target to exclude muscle metaplasia."

"__label__Other I think he may be a very good candidate for gamma-interferon, but unfortunately not every one benefits from this."
"__label__Other I emphasized strongly to he and his wife that his disease may have progressed, or could be made worse by the recent chest surgery and worsened gastroesophageal reflux."
"__label__Other If the disease was, indeed, progressing, we would need to proceed with lung transplantation workup."
__label__obese.mention.before_dct The most significant contraindication currently to transplantation is his substantial obesity.
__label__Other I calculated with him that he needed to have his weight down to 190 lbs.
"__label__Other to get to a BMI of 30, and that by the time of listing he needed to have a BMI of approximately 32."

__label__Other Dear Dr. Yuan:
"__label__cad.mention.before_dct I saw your patient, Bill Fair, in the Cardiology Office today for evaluation of his coronary artery disease in anticipation of knee replacement on March 23, 2085, and thank you for having him come here for evaluation."
__label__Other I will be sending a copy of this letter to
__label__Other Dr. Oliver Oates as evaluation for preop assessment as well.
__label__cad.mention.before_dct Mr. Fair is a 61-year-old male who has a number of risk factors for coronary artery disease but is unaware of any known prior manifestations.
__label__diabetes.mention.before_dct He has had diabetes mellitus for about 20 years.
"__label__medication.insulin..after_dct About two months ago, he started on insulin, and he is now followed by you at the Endocrine Group."
"__label__Other His most recent glucose had been in the range of 86 with his lipids including total cholesterol of 157, triglycerides 103, HDL of 42, and LDL of 94."
"__label__medication.insulin..after_dct His current medical regimen for these and his other problems include insulin NPH 10 units in the morning, 25 units in the afternoon, glyburide 20 mg q.d., and metformin 1000 mg q.d.."
"__label__medication.ace_inhibitor..after_dct He also takes Lasix 60 mg per day, lisinopril 40 mg per day, and Lipitor 10 mg q.d."
"__label__hypertension.mention.after_dct His other risk factors are notable for hypertension, which has been labile and borderline high in the past."

__label__hyperlipidemia.mention.before_dct He has had hypercholesterolemia and is now doing well on Lipitor.
"__label__smoker.never He does not smoke cigarettes, but he is obese."

"__label__Other His mother died at the age of 74 of mesothelioma, and he has two sisters and one brother who are well."
"__label__Other He had an echo performed on February 2, 2085, in anticipation of his knee surgery in March 2085, and this was notable for a mildly dilated left ventricle with mild concentric LVH."
__label__Other Overall LV function is mildly-to-moderately reduced with an estimated ejection fraction of 40%.
__label__Other The entire inferior and posterior walls were akinetic and thin consistent with myocardial scar.
"__label__Other The apical anterior wall, apical lateral wall, and left ventricular apex were hypokinetic suggestive of myocardial hibernation or scar."
"__label__Other The right ventricle was normal in size and function, the left atrium was mildly dilated, the aortic valve was unremarkable, the mitral valve was slightly thickened with mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation, and the tricuspid valve was structurally normal."

__label__Other He has a superior axis likely related to the inferior MI.
__label__Other The QRS is increased with nonspecific intraventricular conduction delay.
__label__cad.mention.before_dct Mr. Fair clearly has evidence of coronary artery disease with at least one myocardial infarction.
__label__Other This had been entirely asymptomatic and was quite a shock for Mr. Fair to hear this information.
__label__Other We will obtain an adenosine MIBI scan prior to his surgery to be sure we have a better idea of the status of his myocardial perfusion.
"__label__Other In addition, I strongly encouraged him to lose as much weight as possible."
