__label__Other Record date: 2123-12-10
"__label__Other December 10, 2123"
"__label__Other Irvin S. Joshua Morgan, M.D."
__label__Other Veterans Administration Roseburg Healthcare System
__label__Other 81 Goldfinch Lane
"__label__Other Dothan, VT 74727"
__label__Other RE:                   Walter Uribe
__label__Other HBH: 
__label__Other             406-70-33
__label__Other DOB:               3/22/68
__label__Other Dear Dr. Joshua Morgan:
__label__Other I am seeing this 55-year-old gentleman in the office today for evaluation of lymphedema and chronic venous stasis in both lower extremities.
"__label__Other The patient has had innumerable episodes of ulceration, which heal with TubiGrip and Profore dressings ultimately to break down again."
__label__Other The patient has been discharged from the TNA and as I understand it the question is put to me today is whether the patient is a candidate for a Lymphapress.
__label__Other The patient has had chronic bilateral lower extremity discoloration and swelling for over ten years.
__label__Other He has never worn compression stockings.
__label__Other He has had multiple episodes of recurrent ulcers.
__label__Other To the best of his knowledge he has never had phlebitis but has had Unna boots in the past.
"__label__Other The patient denies any prolonged hospitalization, long bone fractures or prior history of DVT."
__label__Other There is no family history of varicose veins or DVT.
__label__Other He has no personal history of cancer or trauma.
"__label__Other He has not been involved in any prolonged travel, does not take any hormone medication and is unemployed."
"__label__obese.mention.after_dct The patient's past medical history is notable for coronary artery disease, congestive heart failure, sleep apnea, peripheral neuropathy, morbid obesity, hypertension and pulmonary hypertension."
"__label__medication.ace_inhibitor..after_dct His current medications include lisinopril, verapamil, metformin, furosemide, aspirin, vitamin C, Spiriva and Advair."
"__label__Other The patient denies any family history of cancer, thrombocytosis, thrombocytopenia or bleeding."
__label__Other The patient was raised in Dothan and lives in Galion.
"__label__smoker.past He does not work, denies alcohol abuse and quit tobacco eight years ago."
"__label__hyperlipidemia.mention.during_dct His review of systems is notable for right upper quadrant pain, dyspnea, glasses, diabetes and hyperlipidemia."
__label__obese.mention.before_dct On physical exam he is a morbidly obese gentleman with intertriginous rashes question fungal origin in the axilla on the right.
__label__Other He has distant breath sounds with fine expiratory wheezes.
__label__Other He has some tenderness in the right upper quadrant to palpation.
__label__Other He has a huge protuberant abdomen.
__label__Other There is no tenderness in the right upper quadrant.
"__label__Other He has bounding carotid, brachial and radial pulses."
__label__Other His femoral pulses are not palpable likely due to his body habitus.
__label__Other On the left his dorsalis pedis is 1+ and on the right his posterior tibial was 2+.
"__label__Other He has huge legs with evidence of stasis dermatitis and lipodermatosclerosis, which is greater on the left than the right."
__label__Other He has prominent varices on his right thigh near the takeoff of what appears to be an anterolateral accessory branch.
"__label__Other He has severe brawny induration, discoloration and superficial ulcers on the right with none on the left."
__label__Other The patient seems somewhat reserved but is quite communicative when prompted.
__label__Other The results of his noninvasive vascular lab studies showed bilateral greater saphenous vein reflux.
__label__Other The reflux is confined to the first accessory saphenous vein in the right leg and the saphenopopliteal junction in the proximal thigh.
"__label__Other It should be noted that the reflux in the saphenopopliteal junction on the right is 0, in the anterolateral saphenous vein on the right it is 3 seconds and in the small saphenous vein on the right the reflux is 3 seconds."
"__label__Other In the deep femoral vein, common femoral and superficial femoral vein there is no reflux."
"__label__Other In contrast on the left there is reflux at the saphenopopliteal junction of a mere 3 seconds, in the proximal greater saphenous vein 3 seconds, midthigh 3 seconds and distal thigh 3 seconds."
__label__Other In the popliteal vein there is no reflux and the small saphenous vein there is 3 seconds.
__label__Other Due to the patient's size it was difficult to identify perforators.
"__label__obese.mention.before_dct In summary, we have a morbidly obese gentleman with mild to moderate reflux on examination and severe stasis dermatitis and discoloration."
__label__Other Thus there is a mismatch between the degree of physical findings and objective laboratory data.
__label__Other I believe that this is the case primarily because the patient cannot lie flat and often sleeps with his legs in a dependent position.
__label__Other Thus he has an ongoing stasis in his legs due to inactivity and dependency.
"__label__obese.mention.after_dct This in addition to his morbid obesity, that is a girth of 385 pounds that presses on his abdomen 24 hours a day, seven days a week and compresses the vena cava as well as the lymphatic drainage of his legs."
"__label__Other All of these factors taken into account contribute to his discoloration, ulceration and lower extremity swelling."
__label__Other The solution to this problem is not an easy one.
__label__Other With his obstructive sleep apnea and abdominal girth the chances of him objectively putting his legs up so they are higher than his belly or heart are nonexistent.
"__label__Other Certainly it is not unreasonable to use a Lymphapress machine to help remove some of the swelling and edema that this patient experiences in his legs, however a Lymphapress is not a maintenance device but is an interventional device."
__label__Other If we do not have a plan as to what to put on his legs after the Lymphapress is removed in between treatments it will be of no long-term benefit.
__label__Other I would recommend that he use a Lymphapress machine and intermittent wraps with 6 to 8 inch ACE wraps.
__label__Other I would always make the tension in the ACE wraps at the level of the ankle and heel greater than the midcalf.
"__label__Other I have given him a prescription for a Lymphapress machine as well as ACE wraps and discussed the relevant components of his care, which are important."
__label__Other I hope that these interventions will help him with his lower extremity edema and swelling.
__label__Other It is unlikely that any intervention at the level of his veins will overcome the terrible hydrostatic pressure of his abdomen and total body girth.
"__label__Other If I can provide any additional information regarding Mr. Uribe, please let me know."
"__label__Other Sincerely,"
"__label__Other Michael D. Roe, M.D."
__label__Other MR/martin                    60-38574514.doc

__label__Other He was ultimately discharged from the hospital with the diagnosis of Costa chondritis.
__label__Other He is describing this pain in his left neck and he wonders if it is somehow related to the pain in his chest.
__label__Other He said he tried gargling with mouthwash some and that did seem to help a little.
__label__Other This neck or throat pain has been going on for the past three days.

"__label__Other She noted that she was not feeling well throughout the morning, and she felt as if she may need to eat something."

__label__Other They both attribute it to the Prilosec.

"__label__Other Abdomen: Soft, nontender, no hepatosplenomegaly or mass."

__label__Other My review of CT scan of the chest shows faint peripheral subpleural reticular pattern with cyst formation and no significant nodules.
__label__Other Impression:
__label__Other 1.
__label__Other Interstitial lung disease - Mild objective impairment by functional status.
"__label__Other Pulmonary function tests - Overall, these were stable, and the CT scan is quite suggestive of pulmonary fibrosis."
"__label__Other However, as I reviewed with the patient and his wife, it is well established that 10% of the time, another disorder, such as occult hypersensitivity pneumonitis or nonspecific interstitial pneumonitis can be found on lung biopsy."
"__label__Other There is no evidence of a rheumatologic disorder nor any evidence of chronic aspiration, other than that associated with GE reflux, to explain his lung disease."
"__label__diabetes.mention.after_dct He would be a very reasonable candidate for gamma interferon, although this likely would necessitate low-dose steroids - the latter treatment would certainly have an impact on his diabetes."
__label__Other 2.
__label__Other GE reflux - This is the main source of his cough and is well established to be associated with pulmonary fibrosis.
"__label__Other If he is able to lose weight and change his lifestyle, he can have very good control of this."
__label__Other 3.
__label__Other Possible mild pulmonary hypertension related to the pulmonary fibrosis.
__label__Other 4.
"__label__Other Possible sleep disorder - Currently is entirely without symptoms, now that his reflux is well controlled."
__label__Other 5.
__label__Other Chronic cough.
__label__Other 6.
__label__diabetes.mention.after_dct Diabetes - Better controlled.
__label__Other 7.
__label__obese.mention.before_dct Obesity - He continues to need aggressive weight loss program.
"__label__Other As I mentioned to him, he would not be a candidate for lung transplantation evaluation while he is at such as weight, but he is starting to make some progress."

"__label__Other 	The faint areas of nodularity at the lung bases, slightly more"

__label__Other EKG:	NSR 80 LAD TWI V1-V5 similar to prior
__label__Other ____________________________________________
"__label__Other Impr:	60 yo F w/longstanding fibromyalgia and bronchiectasis s/p recent MSSA PNA p/w diffuse arthralgias, myalgias and pleuritic CP."
"__label__hypertension.mention.before_dct The constellation of myalgias, arthralgias/synovitis, ?pleurisy, Raynaud's, GERD, HTN and +FH invoke the possibility of scleroderma."
"__label__Other Rarely, a variant of this disease can present without skin manifestations (systemic sclerosis sine scleroderma)."
__label__Other The transient nature of her joint symptomatology is c/w possible crystal disease.
"__label__Other The bilateral hand distribution is typical, but progression to involve other joints such as the knee is not."
__label__Other Postviral arthralgias/myalgias is another consideration given the quick resolution of the process.
__label__Other Her myalgias may well represent underlying fibromyalgia.
__label__Other We recommend
"__label__Other   	If available, past ANA, RF, ESR"

__label__Other myocardial infarction on February of 2072 at which time she
__label__Other underwent cardiac catheterization now showing progressive coronary
__label__Other artery disease and therefore underwent a multi-vessel coronary
__label__Other bypass graft operation including a left internal mammary artery to
"__label__Other her LAD and reverse saphenous vein grafts to her PDA, D1 and obtuse"
__label__Other marginal branch.
__label__Other She underwent repeat catheterization in February
__label__Other of 2073 at the Comfrey Clinic which showed diffuse native disease
__label__Other but apparently no significant bypass graft pathology.
__label__Other She
__label__Other underwent repeat cardiac catheterization in May of 2074 because of
__label__cad.symptom.before_dct a current angina and at this time she had evidence for a 60%
"__label__Other proximal LAD stenosis, a proximal severe circumflex artery stenosis"
__label__Other with no occlusion at the origin at a first obtuse marginal branch

__label__cad.event.before_dct CC: STEMI
__label__Other HPI: 
"__label__hypertension.mention.before_dct 79 yo lady with DM, HTN, HL who presented with new onset chest pain and shortness of breath and was found to have lateral STEMI."
"__label__Other It began last Sunday, when she noticed the new onset of back pain, which progressed and was associated with shortness of breath by Monday."
"__label__Other She apparently called EMS on Tuesday then and en route she had a long run of VT, which responded to 50mg of Lidocaine IV."
__label__Other She was intubated on arrival in the ED for progressive respiratory distress.
__label__Other ECG showed lateral ST elevations and a CT scan of her chest was negative for any signs of aortic dissection.
"__label__diabetes.glucose.during_dct Of note, she was also noticed to have elevated blood sugars in the 500s in the ED with an AG of 20, that came down to 16."
"__label__cad.test.during_dct On immediate LHC, a 100% occlusion of her OM1 was found and recannalized as well as stented with a Vision BMS, resulting in TIMI 2 flow."
__label__Other Her LAD was found to be patent but and her RCA showed diffuse atherosclerosis up to 60% stenosis at most.
"__label__Other LV ventriculogram showed inferior hypokinesis with moderate MR.  An IABP was placed with her initial augmented diastolic pressures recorded in the 80s, which led to the initiation of Levophed, Dobutamine and Dopamine."
"__label__Other A PAC was placed in the cath lab as well with her initial Wedge reported as 19-20,  PAPs in the 50s."
"__label__Other On transfer to the CCU, she was intubated, sedated, being on IV Levophed at 20/hr, Dobutamine at 200/hr and Dopamine at 300/hr."
"__label__Other Her CO was recorded as 6.0, her CI 3.5 with an initial SVR of 1012."
__label__Other Her Temp.
"__label__Other was 96.1, HR 115 bpm, augmented diastolic BP of 124, which subsequently ranged between 70 and 100 on the day of her admission."
__label__Other She spiked a temperature up to 101 on the evening of admission after she received a dose of Levaquin IV in the setting of a rising WBC up to 40K.
"__label__Other Vasopressin was added IV, which provided further support of her MAP."
__label__Other Intermittent NS fluid boluses helped to bring her HR down per RN and supported her MAPs with her PAD ranging between 18-24 and a urine output between 30 and 100 cc/hr.
"__label__Other When her CI dropped to 1.9 around 9.30 pm with an increased SVR of 1550, the cardiac fellow was called and the decision was made to wean her Levophed as tolerated, which was then brought down to 16/hr with her Dopamine having been weaned off and continued Dobutamine and Vasopressin."
__label__cad.event.during_dct The patient was also maintained on Reopro and Heparin IV for her STEMI.

"__label__Other  January 25, 2151 (initial office note) Frank Caldwell:"
__label__Other 	He is a 75 year old man who is referred by Dr. Freda Erickson of Mauston for consultation regarding a biopsy proven adenocarcinoma in the head of the pancreas.
__label__Other He apparently developed some twinge type pain in his right upper quadrant which he describes as    zingers    6 or 7 weeks ago.
__label__Other Work-up then involved imaging with a CT scan which I reviewed but do not have the written report on.
__label__Other This shows a mass in the head of the pancreas abutting and perhaps distorting the portal vein.
__label__Other He has not had any jaundice and does not have any change in his bowel functions.
__label__Other A subsequent endoscopic ultrasound examination confirms the mass in the head of the pancreas with features of portal vein invasion.
__label__Other Fine needle aspiration has confirmed adenocarcinoma.
__label__Other The mass itself is about 2   cm in diameter.
__label__Other His family history does not include any pancreatic cancer but his father had lung cancer.
"__label__smoker.never He denies smoking, drinking but exercises by walking about 5 days a week."
"__label__Other His past surgical history includes a resection of an aortic aneurysm in 2131, cholecystectomy in 2131, prostatectomy for cancer in 2142 and resection of a lung cancer in 2143."
"__label__medication.sulfonylureas..during_dct His current medications include Lipitor 40mg a day, Glyburide 5mg three times a day (he has been taking it for 6     7 years), Lisinopril 5mg a day and a baby aspirin."
__label__Other He is said to be allergic to Sudafed and the dye used for CAT scans (the latter was apparently salivary gland swelling on the day following a CAT scan - - it is unclear whether the two are related).
__label__Other His review of systems also includes kidneys stones and spinal stenosis.
__label__Other He has had some mild recent weight loss.
"__label__Other He denies symptoms of heart disease, neurologic disease or respiratory disease."
__label__Other His review of systems is otherwise unremarkable.
__label__Other I think he is not a candidate for attempted surgical resection at this time.
"__label__Other With the findings consistent with portal vein invasion, he should first be treated with chemoradiation."
"__label__Other He may be a candidate for subsequent surgery, probably not resection but perhaps intra-operative radiation therapy."
"__label__Other I   ve explained this to him, his wife and daughter."
"__label__Other After discussing the various alternatives we have agreed to have him evaluated in the Sawtooth Cancer Clinic for treatment planning for chemoradiation, with consideration of subsequent IORT."
__label__Other He comes from Elk Ridge and probably would prefer to have his treatment carried out at the Elk Ridge Health Center in coordination with us.
__label__Other This seems quite reasonable and we will proceed to set that up.
__label__Other I will also get a CA19-9 today and plan to see him at the completion of his chemoradiation.
__label__Other I spent 45 minutes in consultation and coordination of care.

"__label__cad.mention.before_dct Impression/Recommendations: 84 yo F with CAD, DM, CHF, Htn, HL, and right ankle fracture s/p ORIF on 11/04/81 who presents with poor healing over the medial malleolus, now s/p I&D of the open medial malleolus wound; we were consulted by Dr. Felton for recommendations on antibiotic management."
__label__Other The extent of infection is a surgical diagnosis.
"__label__Other If the swabs were obtained from the superficial wound, then this may represent merely a wound infection which requires 2 weeks of antibiotics."
"__label__Other However if the infection was felt on surgical inspection to extend to the region of the removed hardware, then this represents osteomyelitis by definition, and she will need 6 weeks of IV antibiotics with consideration of the removal of the remaining hardware."
"__label__Other After discussion with the ortho resident, it seems that the culture was obtained from the site of screw removal."
"__label__Other Thus, we have to assume hardware infection with concomitant osteomyelitis."
__label__Other Thus 6 weeks of IV antibiotics is necessary.
"__label__Other We cannot rule out infection of the remaining hardware, however I understand the reluctance to remove the remainder of the hardware by the ortho service."
"__label__Other Thus would pursue 6 week course of therapy, then monitor closely for signs of failure."
__label__Other Continue vancomycin until susceptibilities are available; will determine whether the addition of rifampin in necessary given retained hardware based on susceptibility results
__label__Other Please obtain vanc trough prior to 3rd dose
__label__Other Please obtain LFTs
"__label__Other Patient seen and examined with ID Attending, Dr. Ulysses Xayasane."
__label__Other We will continue to follow along with you.
__label__Other Thank you for the consult.

__label__medication.insulin..after_dct HPI:  The patient is a 41 year old man with a history of non-insulin

__label__Other learned today was recently admitted for deep venous thrombosis and is 
__label__Other presenting for follow up of his DVT.
__label__Other The patient's current medical 
__label__Other problems include:
__label__Other 1.
__label__Other Recent DVT.
__label__Other The patient was admitted between the days of 1-24 and 
__label__Other      1-30 secondary to the development of a right lower extremity DVT.
__label__Other The patient told me that he had been doing well and denied any 
__label__Other      previous trauma to his leg or other predisposing factors such as long 
__label__Other      car or airplane trips and he stated he had been as active as 
__label__Other      previously over the recent few weeks.
__label__Other The patient stated he awoke 
__label__Other      in the morning of the 24th and noted tightness in his right 
__label__Other      quadriceps and right calf.
__label__Other He later developed progressive swelling 
__label__Other      of the leg and therefore presented to the THD emergency 
__label__Other      department.
__label__Other He had lower extremity non-invasives performed which 
__label__Other      confirmed the presence of a right lower extremity DVT.
__label__Other He was 
__label__Other      admitted and heparinized and then Coumadinized prior to discharge.
__label__Other The patient disclosed a history that his daughter had a DVT at the 
__label__Other      time of her pregnancy and therefore a hypercoagulability work-up was 
__label__Other      sent off which was negative.

__label__Other Thank you for sending this patient for neurologic consultation.
__label__Other I have reviewed or collected the primary data and examined the patient personally.
"__label__Other CHIEF COMPLAINT:  62 year-old left handed white male (crossed right handed for writing), with bilateral buttock burning dysesthesias radiating down both lateral lower extremities."
"__label__hyperlipidemia.mention.during_dct HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  The patient is a 62 year-old man with a history of diabetes, hyperlipidemia, asthma, hypertension, attention deficit disorder, diabetic neuropathy and obesity who developed two years of gradually progressive discomfort in the lower extremities."
__label__Other He has gained 40 pounds over the past two years and over that time course has noted that when he stands after about a minute he gets a firing burning pain in the left buttock just lateral to the spine which then radiates down the lateral aspect of the left leg.
"__label__Other If he shifts to his right leg, he gets a similar discomfort one or two minutes later."
__label__Other This is relieved by sitting.
__label__Other It will happen when walking as well.
__label__Other This is distinct from the decrease in sensation and the tingling and cold feeling he gets in his feet due to the diabetic neuropathy.
"__label__Other He has had no back trauma, although he has a torn right ACL in the knee which leads to occasional falls."
"__label__Other Of note, he wears his wallet in his left rear pocket and tightens his belt to keep it at his waist."
__label__Other PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  The past medical history is as above and also includes a superficial varicosity in the right mid calf.
"__label__Other ALLERGIES:  Sulfa, contrast medium, Ambien."
__label__Other FAMILY HISTORY:  Non-contributory.
"__label__medication.arb..before_dct CURRENT MEDICATIONS:  Hytrin, Cozaar 50 mg q. day, Ritalin 20 mg five times per day, glucophage 10 mg t.i.d., Rezulin 400 mg t.i.d., Neurontin 600 mg q.h.s."
__label__Other and Selexa.
__label__Other SOCIAL HISTORY:  He is getting divorced and has four grown children all in good health.
__label__Other BIRTH HISTORY:  He was born with hammer toes and no other family member has this condition.
__label__Other EDUCATION:  He is a Consultant who works in Dupont.
__label__Other SOCIAL HISTORY:  He has limited exercise and diet.
__label__smoker.past He has 30+ year history of cigarette smoking and has has no cigarettes in the last six weeks.
__label__Other He denies alcohol use or recent recreational drug use.
__label__Other He has no HIV risk factors.
__label__Other REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:  System review reveals normal bowel function with frequent small volume urination.
__label__Other He attributes this to his Ritalin use and has not seen a urologist.
__label__Other He has difficulty achieving and maintaining an erection and had only minimal improvement with Viagra.
__label__Other When walking he develops some symptoms of claudication which were immediately relieved by resting.
"__label__Other There is no cardiovascular, respiratory or constitutional symptoms."
__label__hypertension.high_bp.during_dct PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:  General: healthy appearance with a blood pressure of 175/90 in the left arm seated.
__label__Other Pulse of 60 and regular.
__label__Other Carotids 2+ without bruits.

"__label__Other Cranial nerves:  immature cataract, o.s."
__label__Other No evidence of retinopathy.
__label__Other Motor:  normal tone and full strength in upper limbs.
__label__Other Mild 5-/5 weakness in ankle extension bilaterally.
__label__Other Mild distal atrophy in the foot intrinsics.
__label__Other Rapid alternating movements intact.
__label__Other Sensation:  decreased to vibration and joint position in the feet bilaterally.
__label__Other Mild decrease to pin over the medial nerve distribution on the right hand.
"__label__Other The muscle stretch reflexes are absent at the Achilles and 1+ at the patellar, brachial radialis, biceps and triceps with flexor, plantar responses."
__label__Other Finger to nose is accurate in both arms.
__label__Other Gait is steady but distorted by the knee injury and slightly wide based.
__label__Other He has a decreased tandem but can heel walk.
__label__Other He has minimal unsteadiness in the Romberg position.
__label__Other DATA REVIEW:  MR imaging of the lumbosacral spine was performed at Carolinas Medical Center-Mercy and then again several days later at Regional Medical Center Bayonet Point (860-721-0108).
__label__Other Report and films reviewed from Carolinas Medical Center-Mercy demonstrate no obvious focal disc herniation or spinal stenosis but some of the views are suboptimal.
__label__Other The summary report from Bayonet Point suggests there may be some lumbosacral spinal stenosis and I await faxed copy of that report.
__label__Other ASSESSMENT:  
__label__Other 1.
__label__Other Neuropathy.
__label__Other The patient has likely multifactorial reasons for his lumbar spine pain.
__label__Other He did undergo an evaluation by Dr.  Ulysses Harding which is unavailable at this time and one cortisone injection which was not effective at relieving his discomfort.
"__label__Other He likely has a combination of diabetic peripheral neuropathy, sciatic neuropathy and possible lumbosacral spinal stenosis or polyradiculopathy."
__label__Other There is no evidence of diabetic amyotrophy.
"__label__Other I think at this point, an EMG with nerve conduction studies will be most helpful to identify the relevant contributions of these different factors."
__label__Other I have also suggested that he invest in suspenders and carry his wallet in a different pocket to see if this will provide some relief.
__label__Other He has tried a course of non steroidals without effect and I think I would like to begin with a low dose of amitriptyline as a neuropathic pain agent to supplement the Neurontin that he is on for other indications.
__label__Other I will see him back in the office after the EMG has been performed and I have had a chance to review the MR imaging.
"__label__Other Thank you for sending him to my office, it is a pleasure taking care of this gentleman and I am hopeful that we will be able to reduce his discomfort to some degree."
__label__Other The risks and benefits of any recommended or alternative treatments were discussed.
__label__Other DIAGNOSTIC CODE/LEVEL:  C5/peripheral neuropathy.

__label__medication.insulin..after_dct Lantus and Novolog Insulin Guidelines	
__label__Other 1.
__label__smoker.unknown Check blood sugars before meals and at bedtime.
"__label__medication.insulin..after_dct In addition, some meals you may want to check your blood sugar (blood glucose or BG) 1 hour after taking your Novolog."
__label__medication.insulin..after_dct If it is over 150 you may need to take more Novolog with meals or decrease your carbohydrate intake.
__label__Other You do not have to do this at every meal and you can alternate meals and/or days.
"__label__Other For example: Sat check before and after breakfast; Friday - lunch; Thursday - supper,etc."
__label__Other 2.
"__label__Other Be careful of the amount of carbohydrates (breads, pasta, cereal, fruit, etc) you eat at each meal and between meals."
__label__Other Try to average about 60 gms.
__label__Other per meal and 15 gms.
__label__Other for snacks.
__label__Other 3.
"__label__medication.insulin..after_dct The goal for your blood sugars when you get up in the morning and before meals  is 80-110, 1 hour after taking Novolog (at the start of the meal) it is less than 140, and at bedtime 100 to 140."
__label__Other 4.
__label__Other Your insulin may need adjusting several times before those goals can be met.
__label__medication.insulin..after_dct When exercising you may need more carbs or less Novolog with meals.
__label__medication.insulin..after_dct Long-acting insulin:  Lantus (insulin glargine)
__label__Other            Take _14_ units at bedtime.
__label__Other Do not mix with any other insulin.
__label__medication.insulin..after_dct Lantus starts to work in about 1 hr and lasts about 
__label__Other                 24 hours.
__label__Other It has no peak.
"__label__Other If your fasting blood sugar for two or more mornings is more than 120, increase your"
__label__medication.insulin..after_dct                 Lantus by 2 units at the next dose.
__label__Other If it is more than 140 for two mornings then     
__label__Other                 increase by 4 units at the next dose.
__label__medication.insulin..after_dct If your fasting blood sugar is less than 70 then decrease your next dose of Lantus 
__label__Other                  by 2 to 4 units.
__label__medication.insulin..after_dct Short-acting insulin:  Novolog  
"__label__Other Take 16 units of novolog with breakfast, 6 units with lunch, and 10 units with supper "
"__label__Other    (called  ""standing dose"") within 15 minutes of starting eat your meals."
__label__Other Do not take 
__label__Other    standing dose if not eating.
__label__medication.insulin..after_dct Novolog starts to work in 15 minutes and lasts about 2 hours.
__label__Other It peaks in about 1 hour.
__label__Other You need to eat enough carbs to cover this insulin or you will have a low blood sugar.
__label__Other If blood sugar is < 80 take    your standing dose or sliding scale.
__label__Other If < 60 do not take standing 
__label__Other      dose.
__label__diabetes.mention.before_dct Take  Novolog sliding scale (below) in addition to standing dose Novolog at mealtime 
__label__Other If Blood sugar is   125 - 150 take  2 units more
__label__Other                              150 - 200 take 3 units more 
__label__Other                                          201 - 250 take 4 units more  	
__label__Other                                          251 - 300 take 6 units more  
__label__Other  			     301 - 350 take 8  units more 
__label__Other 	 >351 take 10 units more and call MD if blood sugar has not 
__label__Other           decreased or has increased after 2 hours.
__label__medication.insulin..after_dct Bedtime High Blood Sugar:  If your blood sugar at bedtime is greater than 200 take Novolog by the sliding scale below in addition to Lantus.
__label__Other Do not mix the two insulins.
__label__Other Do not take standing dose insulin at bedtime.
__label__Other Have your blood sugar checked 1 to 2 hours after taking novolog at bedtime to make sure you haven't gone too low.
__label__Other If you are below 80 then have a snack and juice to hold you over until morning.
__label__Other If bedtime blood sugar is 201 - 250 take 2 units
__label__Other                                                                           251 - 300 take 3 units
__label__Other                                                                           301 - 350 take 4 units
__label__Other Please follow up with your endocrinologist or primary care practitioner in 1-2 weeks.
__label__Other Bring this paper and your blood sugar results from the time you were discharged.
__label__Other For urgent problems or questions about your blood sugar or insulin call 387-8267 and ask for the page operator.
__label__Other Have beeper #68537 paged (the diabetes specialist on-call will call you back if you leave a message).
__label__Other You may also try my pager anytime (30568) but I am not always available.
"__label__Other Olive Tripp, ACNP, CDE                                                        "

__label__Other Assessment/Plan: 
"__label__hypertension.mention.before_dct 	This is a 79 year old woman with past medical history of DM-2, chronic immunosuppresion (steroid use), RA, HTN, h/o leg ulcers, cellulitis and osteomyelitis, who presents with a 1 week history of left lower extremity swelling and erythema, without other symptomatic complaints, that has been resistant to po treatment"
"__label__Other Cellulitis - this woman is predisposed to cellulitis for a number of reasons, including chronic immunosuppression, diabetes, and prior surgeries to the area that have altered the anatomy and blood supply and lymphatic drainage."

__label__Other She complains of persistent weakness and numbness in her right hand and some pain shooting into her right forearm.

__label__Other She denies any significant pain in the leg.

"__label__Other The right arm harvest site is healed well and the upper arm is soft without any evidence of hematoma, whatsoever."

__label__Other She appears to have intact ulnar and radial function.
__label__Other The lower extremity incision has also healed well and there is a strong Doppler signal over the peroneal artery at the ankle.
__label__Other The foot is warm and well perfused and the previous ischemic lesion on the big toe is healing.
"__label__Other She had a followup graft scan today, which revealed her bypass graft to be patent with no evidence of significant narrowing."
__label__Other The ankle index was measured at 0.88 on the left and 0.64 on the right.
__label__Other ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:  Ms. Ferrara lower extremity circulation is stable and her bypass graft is functioning nicely.
"__label__Other Unfortunately, she appears to have had some neuropathic complication in her right arm that may have been related to her vein harvest surgery."
__label__Other The exam suggests some possible partial comprise of median nerve function.

__label__Other There is no evidence of compression from hematoma and no evidence of infection.

__label__Other OFFICE VISIT (CHC)
__label__Other The patient is seen in followup at the Community Health.
__label__Other He came back from Pennsylvania after being there about a month.
__label__Other He has had an eventful past six months.
"__label__Other In October, he apparently had a TIA or small stroke."
__label__Other He was evaluated with an MRA of his neck and was told that there was not enough blockage to warrant surgery.
__label__Other His symptomatology fortunately clear.
__label__Other His symptoms were related to loss of feeling in his right upper extremity.
"__label__Other About this time, he also developed a traumatic lesion of the left second toe."
__label__Other He apparently develops some cellulitis and was treated with ampicillin.
"__label__Other Not long after this, he went into renal failure."
__label__Other He was told that they could not tell if that was due to the antibiotics or the gadolinium.
"__label__Other According to the patient and his wife, his creatinine went as high as 9."
"__label__Other Fortunately, it is currently back down to 2.4."
__label__Other His toe lesion has been very slow to improve.
__label__Other He describes pain in the toe and often has to sleep in a chair with his foot dependent.
"__label__Other He has seen various physicians and podiatrists in Pennsylvania, without much improvement."
"__label__Other They finally told him, he would do well to come back here for further care and evaluation."
"__label__Other On examination today, I can feel femoral and popiteal pulses."
__label__Other I do not feel any definite pedal pulses on either side but noninvasive study show good pulsatile flow at the calf and transmetatarsal level.
"__label__Other Resting ABI is good, although his diabetic calcinosis probably makes this unreliable."
__label__Other He has some slight pulsatile flow at the right toe level and flat tracings at left toes.
__label__Other He has 1 cm escharover the dorsum of his second toe.
__label__Other There is some erythema of the toe and proximal dorsal forefoot.
__label__Other This certainly has the appearance of some cellulites.
__label__Other There is minimal to no swelling of the toe.
__label__Other We will place him on Keflex 250 mg q.i.d.
__label__Other for 7 to 10 days to see if this helps with any possible associated cellulitis.
__label__Other I will refer him to Dr. Caldwell for recommendations regarding wound quick care and an opinion whether or not hyperbaric oxygen therapy might be worth considering.
__label__Other I do not think there is anything further we can do to improve his distal blood flow.
"__label__Other Further imaging will also be very difficult in view of the possible problems with gadolinium as well as his creatinine, which limit contrast administration."
__label__Other His noninvasive studies suggest that his problems are all diabetic small vessel disease and it is unlikely that we could be of benefit with this.
__label__Other I will await Dr. Caldwell&#8217;s opinions.

Do is an 81-year-old right-handed white woman with seropositive, nodular, erosive rheumatoid arthritis that was diagnosed in 2060, type II noninsulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, vascular insufficiency in her legs, peripheral neuropathy, hearing loss in her left ear, right total hip arthroplasty surgery in 2070, right total knee arthroplasty surgery in 2081, left total knee arthroplasty surgery in 2082, a lumbar fusion performed in 2098 and again in 2099, a sigmoid colonic resection in 2103, cellulitis and osteomyelitis involving her right foot in October 2104, a cataract extracted from her right eye in 2102, a cataract extracted from her left eye in 2103, a transient ischemic attack in June 2106, and cellulitis involving her legs in 2107."
"__label__Other She returns to see me in rheumatologic follow-up at Rheumatology, this morning."
"__label__Other Ms. Do has continued to take prednisone 5 mg by mouth twice daily, Celebrex 200 mg by mouth twice daily, and methotrexate 17.5 mg by mouth weekly, with good control of her joint pain, swelling, and stiffness."
"__label__Other She continues to have difficulty grasping objects with her right hand, dropping objects that are held in that hand."
__label__Other She also experiences numbness in her right ring and little fingers.
__label__Other She wears a neutral resting splint on her right wrist for symptoms that she ascribes to right carpal tunnel syndrome.
"__label__Other She has opted not to undergo surgical treatment of her right ulnar neuropathy, after consultation with Dr. Kyron M. Castaneda of the hand surgery service at OGH."
__label__Other She has experienced inadequate treatment of her pain on Darvocet-N 100 two tablets taken by mouth once daily.
__label__Other She has continued to tolerate methotrexate therapy without symptoms of significant toxicity.
"__label__Other She has not experienced skin rashes, fevers, chills, sores in her nose or mouth, hair loss, cough, shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea."
__label__Other She has continued to tolerate prednisone therapy without adverse symptoms other than for fragility of her skin and easy bruisability.

__label__Other Impression:  
__label__Other Mr. Wood is a 58 yo M w/ Hx of colonic polyps and diverticulosis who presents with 1 day of weakness and lightheadedness secondary to a microcytic anemia.
__label__Other His Hct stabilized at 26 since his transfer from his PCP's office.
__label__Other His anemia is most likely due to lower GI bleeding from either his diverticulosis or from his polyposis given his guiac positive stool in the ER.
__label__Other He is currently hemodynamically stable and he states he feels much better symptomatically.
"__label__Other Given that he hasn't had a follow up colonoscopy since the poorly prepped one in March of this year, he will probably need to be reevaluated by Dr. Narvaez."
"__label__Other Other possible attributing causes of his anemia could be hypothyroidism given his somewhat delayed response, but his DTR were normal."
__label__Other Iron studies will be sent to confirm the probable diagnosis of chronic GI bleeding resulting in iron deficiency anemia.
__label__Other He will not be transfused now given that he is asymptomatic currently and he prefers not to be transfused unless necessary.
__label__Other His syncope could also have been exacerbated from his slight orthostatic hypotension as seen on PE and his high Cre and BUN indicating that he is volume depleted.
__label__Other He will be adequately hydrated to correct his hypotension.
"__label__cad.symptom.during_dct Given his chest pain and syncope, MI will be ruled out, but this is very unlikely given his clinical presentation."
__label__Other His first enzymes were negative and his EKG showed no Q waves or ST changes.
__label__Other Plan: 
__label__Other 1)	GI Bleed
__label__Other a.	Transfuse pRBCs if necessary - Consent and Type and Cross (O +)
__label__Other b.
__label__Other Two large bore IVs if rapid resuscitation is needed
__label__Other c.	Follow Hct Q8H and watch HR and BP for signs of active bleeding
__label__Other d.	Nexium 40 POQD
__label__Other 2)	Heme:  Anemia
__label__Other a.
"__label__Other Send Iron Studies, TSH"
__label__Other b.	FeSO4 325 mg POTID
__label__Other 3)	CV:  
__label__Other Rule out MI:  Enzymes + Monitor

__label__hyperlipidemia.mention.during_dct c.	Hyperlipidemia:  Continue Lipitor

__label__Other LABS
__label__Other pending
__label__Other IMPRESSION
__label__Other 61 yo M s/p heart transplant and ESRD on HD presenting with elevated troponin.
__label__Other The trend of his creatinine from outside hospital is not suggestive of acute coronary syndrome.
__label__Other Troponin leak is a common finding in patients with ESRD on hemodialysis since the hemodynamic changes lead to subendocardial ischemia during short-time ultrafiltration.
"__label__Other On the other hand, due to the difficulty in evaluating ACS in patients that had undergone transplant, will repeat cardiac markers for the next 12 hours and meanwhile, continue medical management with ASA, statin, BB and heparin."
"__label__Other The lower EF on outside echo could suggest as well recent past event of myocardial infarction, especially with the multiple walls demonstrating hypokinesis."
__label__Other &gt; Continue other home meds.
__label__Other &gt; Check CSA level in am.
"__label__Other &gt; Since stable volume status, consider contacting renal in am for further decision about next HD session depending on lab results."
__label__Other &gt; Will continue lasix on nonHD days.
__label__Other &gt; Will defer further testing to primary cardiologist in am.
__label__Other &gt; CPAP at night
__label__Other &gt; Keep NPO after MN.
"__label__Other &gt; Will check PTH, iron store, Ca/PO4 and 25 vitD."

"__label__Other Henry Norris, MD"

__label__Other Dear Dr.
__label__Other Craft:
__label__Other I had the pleasure of meeting Peter Joshi in the Cardiology Clinic on February 24th.
__label__Other Mr. Joshi presents with a complaint
__label__Other of dyspnea and oxygen requirement.
__label__Other The patient does relate that
"__label__Other he has had breathing problems in the past and in fact, markedly"
__label__Other worse several years ago.
"__label__Other However, with the treatment of his"
"__label__cad.mention.before_dct coronary artery disease, he had been doing somewhat better until"
__label__Other he underwent surgery for a carotid artery stenosis.
__label__Other Since that
"__label__Other surgery several months ago, he has had a prolonged period of time"
__label__Other during which he has required supplemental oxygen.
__label__Other At the same
"__label__Other time, the patient is being treated for congestive heart failure"
"__label__Other and in fact, has had a recent increase in his dose of standing"
__label__Other Lasix.
"__label__Other The patient relates that during his hospitalization, he"
"__label__Other did have what sounds like a pleural effusion, which a physician"
"__label__Other did try to drain, however, unsuccessfully."
"__label__Other At the current time,"
__label__Other Mr. Joshi is feeling slowly better and feels as though he is
"__label__Other able to take a deep breath, which he was unable to do several"
__label__Other months ago.
"__label__Other In fact, he was told recently that he does not need"
__label__Other supplemental oxygen.
"__label__Other He denies a chronic cough, although he does"
__label__Other occasionally have some difficulty swallowing which leads to
__label__Other coughing.
"__label__diabetes.mention.after_dct His past medical history includes diabetes, carotid artery"
"__label__cad.mention.before_dct stenosis, coronary artery disease with both angioplasty and stent"
"__label__Other placement, congestive heart failure, bladder cancer,"
"__label__hypertension.mention.after_dct hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, gastroesophageal reflux, and"
__label__Other upper GI bleed.
__label__Other      MR #453-39-84-4                -2-                 02/24/70
"__label__medication.aspirin..after_dct His medications include aspirin, Lasix, Isordil, Zestril,"
"__label__medication.calcium_channel_blocker..before_dct Lopressor, simvastatin, Norvasc, Prevacid, a multi vitamin,"
"__label__medication.insulin..after_dct potassium, albuterol, Atrovent, Serevent, and insulin."
__label__Other He has no known drug allergies.
__label__Other He discontinued cigarette
__label__Other smoking years ago.
"__label__Other On exam today, he had a blood pressure of 122/60."
__label__Other His pulse was
"__label__Other 56, afebrile."
"__label__Other O2 sat on room air initially was at 90%, but when"
"__label__Other I rechecked it, it was 95%."
__label__Other His weight was 221 lbs.
__label__Other He is in no
__label__Other respiratory distress at rest.
__label__Other His oropharynx had dry mucosa and
__label__Other a somewhat small posterior pharyngeal air space.
__label__Other His neck had no
__label__Other enlarged lymph nodes.
__label__Other Chest had diminished breath sounds in the
__label__Other left base with crackles.
__label__Other His right lung was clear.
__label__Other His heart
__label__Other was in a regular bradycardic rhythm with a II/III systolic
__label__Other murmur.
"__label__Other His abdomen was protuberant, but benign."
__label__Other His
__label__Other extremities are with 1+ pitting edema and no clubbing.
__label__Other Pulmonary
__label__Other function testing had been performed in December and was repeated
"__label__Other again today, which demonstrates that he has a combined"
__label__Other restrictive and obstructive ventilatory defect.
__label__Other His current
__label__Other vital capacity was improved approximately 10% from that of
__label__Other December.
__label__Other He has no bronchodilator response.
__label__Other I took Mr. Joshi
__label__Other for a short walk and he never desaturated below 92% and that
__label__Other includes after walking up one flight of stairs.
"__label__Other In summary, I believe that Mr. Joshi has dyspnea which is likely"
__label__Other mostly related to congestive heart failure and deconditioning.
"__label__Other However, I do believe he might have a pleural effusion based on"
"__label__Other my exam and based on his history and therefore, I have referred"
__label__Other him to have a decubitus chest film taken.
__label__Other Mr. Joshi had several
__label__Other questions related to his metered dose inhaler use and I have
__label__Other recommended that he use only Combivent 4x a day regularly.
__label__Other I do
__label__Other not believe there is any benefit to be gained from an inhaled
__label__Other corticosteroid for this gentleman.
__label__Other I do recommend that he get
__label__Other daily exercise.
__label__Other He certainly needs to continue his diuresis and
__label__Other I will certainly check his chest x-ray on the outside chance that
__label__Other he may benefit from            a pleural effusion.
__label__Other I have also
__label__Other confirmed to him that he no longer requires supplemental oxygen.
__label__Other His pulmonary function testing also had demonstrated a reduced
"__label__Other defusion capacity, however, it does correct when accounting for"
__label__Other albuterol volume and therefore do not believe that he is likely
__label__Other to have either an interstitial lung disease or pulmonary 
__label__Other      MR #453-39-84-4                -3-                 02/24/70
__label__Other vascular disease.
"__label__Other However, we will certainly reassess this after"
__label__Other his initial work-up.

__label__cad.event.before_dct I had the pleasure of seeing Nick Hall in WSH cardiology clinic today in follow-up for his known coronary artery disease and recent admission to Wytheville South with a non-ST elevation myocardial infarction.
"__label__cad.event.before_dct As I'm sure you recall, he is a lovely 54 year old gentleman whose history of Hodgkins disease status-post mantle radiation in the early 70's, squamous cell lung cancer status post left upper lobectomy 1/94, and coronary artery disease, status post-PCI to the LAD and RCA in '90 and '87, respectively, and perioperative VT/VF arrest at the time of his LUL resection 1/94."
"__label__cad.event.before_dct At that time, emergent catheterization revealed massive volume of thrombus extending throughout his RCA, managed with extensive suction catheter use and POBA, with a good angiographic result."
__label__cad.mention.during_dct No stents were placed given the thrombus burden.
"__label__Other Remarkably, subsequent echocardiogram revealed normal LV systolic function, with basal inferoposterior HK noted."
"__label__cad.test.before_dct His peak TnI was 33.6, his peak CK was 1710, and his peak MB was 87.2."
"__label__medication.thienopyridine..after_dct He had a relatively unremarkable course post-catheterization; plavix initiation was delayed until his chest tube was removed, after which it was started without incident."
"__label__cad.symptom.before_dct He was discharged 2/11/94, and had done well until 1/31/2095, when he presented to WSH with unstable angina, having noted new sudden onset angina and dyspnea while making his daily walk."
"__label__cad.mention.during_dct He had a positive troponin, and was taken urgently to cardiac catheterization, which revealed a proximal LAD lesion (felt to be the culprit) and ostial RCA lesion, both of which were stented with CYPHER stents."
"__label__medication.thienopyridine..after_dct At that time the decision was made to increase his plavix from 75 to 150 as an attempt to maximize his medical management, given his history and disease burden."
"__label__Other Since that admission, he has done exceedingly well, and presents today without complaints."
__label__Other He continues to walk 2 miles ~4 times/week without exertional symptoms.
"__label__Other He specifically denies chest pain, dyspnea, orthopnea, PND, or lower extremity edema."
"__label__Other He has had no palpitations, dizziness/presyncope, or claudication."
"__label__Other He has significantly modified his diet to eliminate dairy and hydrogenated products/snacks, with a 5# weight loss, and is motivated to further reduce his weight."
"__label__Other He states that he feels ""great"" and isdoing quite well."
"__label__Other He does not that occasionally at this work, when he is frustrated/upset, he will take his pressure and find his systolic to be ~150, but this comes down within minutes if he relaxes, and his pressures are great at home."
"__label__Other He has had no GI symptoms on the aggressive antiplatelet regimen, despite not being on a PPI."
"__label__Other Regarding his squamous cell lung cancer, it is my understanding that he had no evidence of metastatic disease and that margins were negative; he is not currently planned for any adjuvant therapy, but will be closely followed."

__label__Other SCM and traps 5/5.
"__label__Other Motor:	UMN pattern weakness in RUE (4-/5), most notable in hands."
__label__Other Mild  proximal RLE weak (4+/5).
"__label__Other Coord:	Impaired FTN in LUE, intact in RUE."
"__label__Other Refl:	Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ at biceps, triceps, brachioradialis, patella, and ankles."
__label__Other Plantar response is flexor on right and extensor on left.
__label__Other Sens:              Decreased PP but NOT LT in LUE and LLE 
__label__Other Imaging: 
__label__Other MRI Brain (9/25/75)     DWI bright ADC dark right lateral medullary pyramid with associated increased T2 signal.
__label__Other MRA Head/Neck (9/25/75)     Narrowing of basilar artery with flow signal throughout and no thrombosis  
"__label__Other CTA Head/Neck (9/25/75)     Diffuse atherosclerotic disease, occluded R-ICA with good collateralization of right hemisphere, severe irregular narrowing through out bilateral vertebral arteries and basilar arteries."
"__label__hypertension.mention.before_dct IMPRESSION: The patient has numerous risk factors for stroke with HTN, DM2, and HLP."
__label__Other His exam is consistent with lateral medullary pyramid lesion with involvement of spinalcortical tract prior to decussation explaining ipsilateral weakness and also involvement of the spinalthalamic tract explaining contralateral deficit in pain sensation.
"__label__Other His vessel imaging is notable and concerning for diffuse atherosclerotic disease, specifically in posterior circulation in distribution of acute stroke."
"__label__Other The patient was reportedly taking aspirin, though reports are mixed and this needs clarification."
"__label__Other Vessel imaging did not implicate that the patient suffered from acute vertebro-basilar thrombo-embolism, but that his posterior circulation disease is a chronic issue and the stroke was more likely due to distal vessel thrombosis."
"__label__Other Anticoagulation can be considered in acute setting of small sized posterior circulation stroke with vertebro-basilar disease, but in this case by the time the patient became known to neurology service and by the time it was known he had a stroke it was some 24hrs after initial symptoms, and in this interval he did not show any signs or symptoms of stroke progression making unstable plaque unlikely."
"__label__Other Given the findings of the WASID study that anticoagulation did not significantly improve recurrent stroke prevention benefits over aspirin for symptomatic vertebro-basilar disease (because warfarin benefits were offset by higher hemorrhage rates), the decision to place this patient on aspirin is supported."
"__label__hypertension.mention.before_dct The long term management of this patient requires aggressive control of atherosclerotic risk factors such as HTN, DM2, and HLP."
"__label__Other The patient is significantly at risk of major ischemic stroke due to occluded right carotid artery and diffuse posterior circulation disease, and it is conceivable that if he continues to have persistent symptoms in the future that a revascularization procedure may be necessary."
__label__Other RECOMMENDATIONS:

__label__Other a composite of the following three major changes in his medical
__label__Other regimen.

__label__Other and this has been associated with a symptomatic stability.
__label__Other He
"__label__Other had biventricular pacing box placed, certainly contributing to"
__label__Other his overall improved status and he is now taking a regular dose
__label__Other of Lasix.
__label__Other He is on 80 mg alternating with 40 mg per day.
"__label__Other does have symptoms of fatigue, but his overall volume status is"
__label__Other quite reasonable.
__label__Other He is currently on Aldactone 25 mg daily and
"__label__medication.ace_inhibitor..after_dct Lasix 80 mg per day alternating with 40 mg per day, Captopril"
__label__Other 6.25 mg p.o.
"__label__medication.insulin..before_dct t.i.d., Zocor, insulin, Glucophage, aspirin, and"
__label__Other mexiletine.
__label__Other His amiodarone has been discontinued.
__label__Other He does have
"__label__Other asymptomatic ventricular tachycardia, often paced out of this,"
__label__Other but I am reluctant to recommend ablation therapy for him at the
__label__Other present time.

__label__Other Functionally he seems quite stable.

__label__Other but is otherwise reasonably active.

__label__Other traveling to Miami this spring.

__label__Other HPI:
"__label__diabetes.mention.during_dct Mr. Eubanks is a 68 year-old man with hypertension, mild diabetes mellitus type II, and gout who presents with 2 hours of burning chest pain prominent in the left anterior chest and radiating to both arms and to the center of the back."
"__label__hypertension.mention.before_dct In addition to HTN and DM, Mr. Eubanks    cardiac risk factors include a family history of CAD (brother, sister) and prior history of mild, spontaneously resolving chest pain in early 2147."
"__label__Other He received a cardiac workup for the chest pain including baseline EKG, exercise tolerance test, and Myoview study."
"__label__cad.event.before_dct Baseline EKG was unremarkable with normal sinus rhythm but the ETT was positive with inverted T waves, ST segment downsloping depressions in the anterolateral and inferior leads, and PVC   s in recovery."
"__label__Other The patient had no chest pain and good exercise capacity during the ETT, which was terminated after 9 minutes because of leg fatigue."
"__label__Other On the Myoview study, a small area of ischemia with possibly minimal scaring was noted in the inferior wall although wall motion was normal."
__label__Other Estimated left ventricular ejection fraction was 62%.
__label__Other A subsequent exercise echo was normal.
__label__hypertension.high_bp.during_dct Baseline blood pressures at the time of the workup measured 160/68 with systolic pressures noted as high as 180.
__label__medication.beta_blocker..during_dct His blood pressure has been since controlled on atenolol and was measured per patient account to be around 148/80 at his most recent visit to his PCP in August.
__label__diabetes.mention.after_dct Hemoglobin A1C in 2147 was 6.2 and diabetes has been managed with only diet.
__label__medication.aspirin..during_dct He was previously using daily aspirin but stopped in October 2148 for a dermatologic surgery and did not restart.
"__label__Other Mr. Eubanks was in his usual state of health until 3 days prior to admission when he developed two episodes of low grade chest pain, once in the morning and once in the evening."
"__label__Other These episodes lasted only 1-2 minutes, and seemed to him to be related to his ongoing issues with gout."
"__label__Other The chest pain was not associated with shortness of breath and seemed to improve with indomethacin, which he typically takes for acute exacerbations of gout."
__label__Other His course over the next two days was unremarkable and he went to bed comfortable the night prior to admission.
__label__cad.symptom.before_dct He was awakened near 3 am by 8/10 burning chest pain and pressure in the left anterior chest and radiating to both arms and to the center of his back but not to the neck or jaw.
"__label__Other Associated with the chest pain were chills and a feeling of increased heart rate although the patient denies shortness of breath, sweating, nausea or vomiting, headache, lightheadedness, fever, or vision changes."
"__label__Other The pain persisted for 2 hours without improvement or alleviating factors, prompting the patient to have his wife drive him to BBH ED from his Cheney home."
"__label__Other Review of systems was positive for polyuria, increased thirst, mild non-productive cough, post-nasal drip, and intermittent mild diarrhea in past months."
"__label__Other The patient denies recent or past history of edema, GERD, claudication, clots, hemoptysis, hematemesis, dyspnea on exertion, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, wheezing, fatigue, appetite or weight changes, or night sweats."

__label__Other Assessment:
"__label__hypertension.mention.before_dct Mr. Eubanks is a 68 year-old man with HTN, DM II, and gout, who presents with 2 hours of severe chest pain."
"__label__cad.event.before_dct The differential for chest pain is broad and includes cardiac ischemia, myocardial infarction, aortic dissection, pneumothorax, pulmonary embolus, bronchitis, pleurisy, GERD/esophageal spasm, musculoskeletal/chest wall pain, and anxiety."
"__label__Other The sudden onset of severe chest pain, awaking him from sleep, raises the probability of an acute cardiac or pulmonary event such as MI, aortic dissection, or PE."
"__label__Other The patient has elevated D-Dimer but otherwise lacks physical exam findings (dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, cough, hemoptysis, tachypnea, signs of DVT) or CT/CTA imaging features consistent with pulmonary embolism."
"__label__hypertension.mention.before_dct The patient   s HTN is a risk factor for aortic dissection, but this diagnosis can be ruled out by negative CXR and CTA scans, which have 80     95% sensitivity."
"__label__Other In addition, he lacks a number of other clinical manifestations of dissection, including syncope, pulse deficits, and new murmur."
__label__medication.nitrate..during_dct The distribution of the pain is anginal in distribution and is relieved by nitroglycerin + aspirin.
"__label__Other Moreover, the patient has had two similar but less severe attacks a few days ago, and has multiple cardiac risk factors."
__label__cad.event.before_dct This makes unstable angina or myocardial infarction the most likely diagnosis.
"__label__Other EKG changes lacked ST segment elevation, although T-wave inversions were present in some leads."
__label__Other The patient   s cardiac enzymes were negative from the ED x 2 sets with a third troponin negative on the floor.
__label__Other The patient may have either a non-ST elevation MI or unstable angina.
"__label__Other The plan will be to continue monitoring closely for chest pain and EKG changes, with the next step likely to involve stress test or catheterization in the morning tomorrow."
__label__Other Cardiology is following closely and has provided recommendations that are incorporated into the plan.
__label__Other Plan:  
__label__Other 1.
__label__Other Chest pain
"__label__Other Telemetry, cardiac monitor"
"__label__Other Troponin, CK, CK-MB q8h x 3"
__label__Other LDH on next draw
__label__Other EKG if chest pain reemerges or in AM if no chest pain flare
__label__medication.aspirin..during_dct ASA 325 mg po qd
__label__medication.beta_blocker..after_dct Metoprolol 37.5 mg PO q8h
__label__medication.nitrate..during_dct Nitroglycerin 0.3 mg 1 tablet prn chest pain
"__label__Other If chest pain continues, enzymes positive, EKG changes    add IV heparin"
"__label__Other If chest pain flare, enzymes positive, or EKG changes, consider catheterization."

__label__Other PNA and tumor are less likely given the lack of fevers and chills and any hx of weight loss.

__label__Other He also has a history of bicuspid aortic valve with mild-to-moderate stenosis on recent echos and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation.
__label__cad.event.before_dct He is status post a posterolateral MI in 2084 and had an adenosine MIBI in January 2097 with an old inferior MI and peri-infarct ischemia.
"__label__cad.symptom.during_dct He presented with increasing angina with exertion where he is able to do most activities and climb stairs and walk his dog, but does have about one episode of angina a week while raking leaves that last about 5 minutes and resolves with rest."
__label__Other He has not had any rest pain.
"__label__Other For his increasing angina, he had an attempted cardiac catheterization done last month, but they are unable to advance the guidewire pass the iliac artery and an MRI was able to determine that he has an occluded aorta."
__label__Other He then had a left brachial artery.
__label__cad.mention.before_dct Cardiac catheterization that revealed extensive coronary disease with a 70-80% distal left main stenosis and severe disease of the LAD and circumflex with minimal flow and a subtotal occlusion of the proximal right coronary with collateralization from the LAD territory.
"__label__Other There was an anomalous circumflex that appeared to emerge from the right coronary and there was a question of his anomalus LAD with a separate ostium superior to the left main, but the documentation of this was not clear."
"__label__Other With the complexity of his anatomy, he is referred for further evaluation."
"__label__smoker.past He has otherwise a history of cigarette smoking and quit three months ago, does not drink alcohol."
__label__Other He is married and lives in Missouri.

"__label__Other Blood pressure of 128/60, pulse of 60-70 and room air sat of 99%."
__label__Other He had no jugular venous distention.
__label__Other Chest was clear.
__label__Other Heart had normal S1 and S2.
__label__Other No S3 or S4.
__label__Other There is a 2/6 systolic ejection murmur along the left sternal border.
__label__Other His abdomen was benign.

"__label__Other His labs showed a BUN/creatinine of 21/1.3, glucose 145 and hematocrit of 40%."

__label__Other We will try and define better his actual anatomy and likely do act angiogram to try and identify the locations of any anomalus vessels and then have a surgical consults regarding bypass surgery for his left main extensive disease.

__label__Other Neurology Clinic Follow-up
__label__Other ID:  50 RHM s/p large R MCA stroke 10/20/69 with subsequent hemicraniectomy complicated by abdominal and head wound infections
__label__Other HPI:  Patient presented initially 10/20/69 after a fall due to the acute onset of left-sided weakness.
"__label__Other Head CT showed hypodensity in the R MCA territory, and CTA revealed R ICA occlusion."
__label__Other The patient was admitted to the neuroICU.
__label__Other Follow-up head CT the morning after admission revealed hypodensity involving the entire R MCA territory.
"__label__Other Because of malignant swelling, he went on to require hemicraniectomy which was performed by the Simmons Neurosurgery service."
__label__Other He recovered and was discharged to rehab on 10/28 with left hemiplegia and dense left-sided neglect.
__label__medication.aspirin..before_dct Aspirin was prescribed for stroke prophylaxis but was subsequently stopped at rehab for unclear reasons.
__label__Other His stroke work-up revealed a normal echocardiogram and 24-hr Holter monitor.
__label__Other A hypercoagulability panel was negative.
__label__Other Homocysteine was normal.
__label__Other Serum lipid analysis revealed mild hypertriglyceridemia.
__label__Other The patient was re-admitted on 12/02 with an abdominal bone flap infection.
__label__Other The flap was removed and long-term antibiotics prescribed.
"__label__Other He did well and then was re-admitted 01/01 with fever, headache, nausea, and vomiting."
__label__Other His hemicraniectomy site revealed protruding brain which required revision in the OR.
__label__Other Long-term antibiotics were again prescribed for possible infection of the site.
"__label__Other The patient did well, but routine follow-up MRI of the cranium on 3/8 shows a large, rim-enhancing, DWI bright fluid collection adjacent to the hemicraniectomy site."
__label__Other This may represent abscess.
"__label__Other Dr. Bennett, Simmons Neurosurgery attending, intends to admit Mr. Rico 3/27 for fluid sampling and culture."
__label__Other Additional operative intervention may be indicated if this fluid collection is indeed infected.

__label__Other He has had headaches frequently during the past couple of weeks.
__label__Other This was a major problem early in his course but then resolved.
"__label__Other Mr. Rico has now been out of rehab for 2 months, and he is doing quite well."
__label__Other He is able to walk with the assistance of a four-post cane.
"__label__Other His appetite is good, and he sleeps well on trazodone."

__label__Other His spirits have been good considering the ordeal he has recently been through.

__label__Other He cries when he tells me about this.

__label__Other He is able to assist with ADLs but cannot function independently.

__label__Other There are occasional twitches in the thumb that are not voluntary.

__label__cad.event.before_dct IDENTIFICATION:  This 65-year-old man with a 5-year history of cardiomyopathy is is admitted with worsening heart failure and recent presyncope for further evaluation.
__label__Other He was diagnosed with progressive shortness of breath in 2078.
__label__medication.diuretic..before_dct He was treated with diuretics and other medications at that time.
__label__cad.event.before_dct He did quite well until December of last year when he had a cardiac arrest and underwent ICD placement.
__label__Other He has had worsening symptoms over the last year with increasing shortness of breath on flat ground and a very severe shortness of breath with stairs.
__label__Other He has had some episodic nature to this.
"__label__Other Two days prior to admission, he had relatively rapid onset of shortness of breath while trying to play pool."
__label__Other This recurred several times associated with diaphoresis.
__label__Other He had no palpitations at that time.
__label__Other He has no chest discomfort.
__label__Other His past medical history is significant for history of shower emboli and TIA in 2081.
__label__diabetes.mention.after_dct He has diabetes.
__label__Other He had spinal stenosis surgery in 2078.
"__label__medication.diuretic..during_dct His current medical regimen is Bumex 3, recently decreased from 12 due to worsening renal function."
"__label__medication.beta_blocker..before_dct He is on spironolactone described as 6.25 daily, digoxin 0.125, Toprol-XL 12.5."
"__label__medication.beta_blocker..before_dct He has been on carvedilol, which was changed due to dizziness."
__label__medication.ace_inhibitor..before_dct He is on lisinopril 1.25 mg and has had great difficulty tolerating any higher dose due to dizziness.
__label__medication.diuretic..after_dct He is on metolazone 2.5 weekly.
__label__Other He takes Coumadin 7.5 mg most days.
__label__medication.insulin..during_dct He is on insulin and Lantus.
__label__Other He has no known drug allergies.
__label__Other His family history is essentially unremarkable.
"__label__Other Mother unknown, father had onset of angina in his 80s."
__label__Other The patient lives with his wife and son and is a retired Fire Chief.
__label__smoker.past He had an 80-pack-year smoking history but quit four years ago.
__label__Other He has one glass of alcohol every 1-2 weeks.
"__label__Other Review of systems is negative for any problems with fevers, chills, change in his bowel or bladder habits."
__label__Other He has no problems with swallowing.
__label__Other He has no problems with hearing or vision.
__label__Other Review of systems is otherwise negative.
"__label__Other On physical examination, blood pressure is 84/66 in the left arm and 86/62 in the right arm."
__label__Other His chest is completely clear to auscultation and percussion.
__label__Other Temperature is 35.9.
__label__Other His heart rate is 100 and a regular rhythm.
"__label__Other His cardiac exam reveals left ventricular heave, which is visible."
__label__Other He has a palpable and audible third heart sound.
__label__Other The right ventricular impulse is present also.
"__label__Other He has a systolic murmur, which is heard everywhere, not otherwise easy to characterize."
__label__Other It does not change with respiration.
__label__Other The second component of the second sound is slightly increased in radiation consistent with a PA systolic pressure in the range of 50-60.
__label__Other His legs are cool.
__label__Other Venous pattern is very prominent.
__label__Other His pulses are intact peripherally.
__label__Other He has no abdominal bruits.
__label__Other His jugular venous pressure is 14 cm.
__label__Other He has no cervical adenopathy or thyromegaly.
__label__Other His liver percusses at approximately 5 cm below the costal margin.
__label__Other He has some increased resonance around the umbilicus.
"__label__Other Laterally, there is suggestion of some fluid in the distention."
__label__Other There is no peripheral edema.
"__label__Other His joints are without obvious deformities, although he describes arthritis in his shoulder, neck, and back."
"__label__Other He has no skin rashes or sores, several very small ecchymoses."
__label__Other His standing blood pressure is unchanged.
__label__Other He has atrially triggered ventricular pacing at 98.
__label__Other ASSESSMENT:
__label__Other 1.
__label__Other Etiology of left ventricular dysfunction is undetermined.
__label__Other We do not know information of recent catheterization or echocardiography.
__label__Other The degree of his mitral disease is not clear.
__label__Other He clearly did not have coronary artery disease on one studied initially.
"__label__Other However, the episodicity is significant."
__label__Other 2.
"__label__Other Current hemodynamic status shows marked volume overload and low cardiac output, and is cold and wet pattern."
__label__Other His history of recent diuretic use suggests that he may have had relatively rapid onset of fluid after his last diuretic change.
"__label__Other However, the episode while playing pool also raises the possibility of a ventricular tachyarrhythmia undetected."
__label__Other It is also possible that this is related to angina.
__label__Other 3.
__label__Other Other related risks.
__label__Other He is on Coumadin due to his embolic shower before.
"__label__Other It is possible that he has had other emboli, possibly even to coronary arteries leading to recent decline in function."
__label__Other There are no obvious contraindications to transplant.
"__label__Other At this time, we are not planning to evaluate him but to treat the urgency of his heart failure decompensation."
"__label__Other Our plan is to hold his beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors for now, and to begin him on an IV diuretic infusion."
__label__Other We will proceed with echocardiogram and catheterization if necessary to determine whether there are other conditions exacerbating his current decompensated state.

__label__cad.event.before_dct Impression and Plan:  Mr. Ocampo is making a slow but study recovery from his multivessel coronary bypass graft surgery.
__label__Other I suggested he undergo repeat echocardiogram to document current left ventricular function now that he is back in sinus rhythm.
"__label__Other I told him he would stay on amiodarone for approximately 3-6 months, and assuming, he was in normal sinus rhythm throughout this time period, his amiodarone would then be discontinued."

"__label__diabetes.mention.after_dct INTERN/MED STUDENT ADMIT NOTE, Team 3"
__label__Other Name:  Mr. Danny Nielson
__label__Other MR #:  9156593
__label__Other Date of admission: 08/28/2097
"__label__Other Admitting Physician: Dr. Gene Quadri, MD	"
__label__Other PCP: Dr. Ulises Noel
"__label__Other Source of Hx:  Patient, Available note"
__label__Other Code: Full
__label__Other CC:     Want to get my chemo   
__label__Other ID: Mr. Nielson is a 77 yoM w/ Stage IIIB diffuse large B-cell lymphoma s/p 4 cycles of CHOP and 1 cycle of R-ICE who presents now for cycle 2 of R-ICE.
__label__Other HPI:   Mr. Nielson was in his usual state of health until March of this year when he began noticing increasing swelling in his left leg over a period of three weeks.
__label__Other He also developed b/l groin swelling greater on the left; the swelling in the left groin was tender.
"__label__Other He presented in early April where CT and PET scan of the pelvis and abdomen revealed a 6.0 cm inguinal node, a chain of nodes in the retrocrural space, adenopathy in the external iliac chain (largest 3.5 cm), and two nodes in the retroperitoneal space in between the IVC and aorta."
__label__Other He underwent biopsy of the left groin mass two weeks later revealing DLBCL confimed by immunophenotyping.
"__label__Other Subsequent bone marrow biopsy revealed polyclonal B-cell populations and an inverted CD4/CD8 T Cell ratio, with no evidence of monoclonal proliferation."
"__label__Other The patient underwent his initial two cycles of CHOP in May, and experienced no adverse effects except for generalized weakness."
"__label__Other PET exam in early June revealed larger left groin mass, improvement in lymphadenopathy, and a small pancreatic cystic lesion."
__label__Other It was undetermined whether this represented treatment effect or worsening of disease.
__label__Other The patient subsequently had his next two CHOP treatments in mid June and early July.
__label__Other PET scan and lymph node biopsy in early July revealed unchanged disease with evidence of fibrosis and inflammation.
"__label__Other The patient was seen in clinic by Dr. Quadri twice in July, with the second visit revealing increased PET avidity and persistence of the primary mass."
"__label__diabetes.mention.after_dct Given the persistence of the mass and lack of response to CHOP, the patient was evaluated by Dr. Rodgers of the WDMC one week later on 7/28 for consideration of auto-SCT vs more aggressive chemo regimen."
"__label__Other Due to the patient's age and consideration of risk/benefit, it was decided that the best approach would be to attempt a more aggressive chemo regimen first."
__label__Other Mr. Nielson was admitted on 8/2/2097 to receive his first cycle of R-ICE with dose-reduced Ifos and carboplatin becuase of h/o nephrectomy.
__label__Other He tolerated the treatment fairly well with some panycytopenia.
__label__Other Patient felt the R-ICE regimen was a little    harder    on him than the CHOP regimen.
__label__Other He felt effects including fatigue and constipation that resolved back to baseline in a few days.
"__label__Other On 8/9, he was given 2 units of packed red cells due to anemia and on 8/16, he was given a unit of pheresis platelets for his thrombocytopenia as well as two units of packed red blood cells for his anemia."
__label__Other He was initially scheduled to receive cycle 2 of R-ICE on 8/22 but that was delayed due to his thrombocytopenia.
__label__Other He says that he currently feels cold-intolerance and fatigue that is the same as when he first started his chemotherapy in May.

__label__Other Re:  Dalila Haynes
